A two-time former presidential election candidate in [[South Korean presidential election, 2012|2012]] and [[South Korean presidential election, 2017|2017]], Ahn is currently the [[Bareunmirae Party]]'s candidate for the [[Seoul]] [[Mayor of Seoul|mayorship]].{{Cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3046505|title=Ahn Cheol-soo declares bid for Seoul mayor|website=Korea JoongAng Daily|access-date=2018-04-05}} He ran as an independent candidate for the [[South Korean presidential election, 2012|presidential election in 2012]], but withdrew a month before the election took place to support [[Moon Jae-in]] whom he ran against in 2017 as the [[People's Party (South Korea, 2016)|People's Party]] nominee. He was a founding co-leader and the party leader of the People's Party until his party and [[Bareun Party]] merged as [[Bareunmirae Party]] in February 2018. Prior to politics, Ahn founded [[AhnLab, Inc.]], an [[antivirus software]] company, in 1995. He was chairman of the board and [[Chief Learning Officer]] of AhnLab until September 2012, and remains the company's largest stakeholder. Prior to entering politics, Ahn served as dean of the Graduate School of Convergence Science and Technology at [[Seoul National University]] until September 2012. ==Early life and education== Ahn was born on 26 February 1962, in [[Miryang]], [[South Korea]], while his father was on military service there; he subsequently moved with his family to [[Busan]], where he grew up.{{cite news|url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/555525.html|title=The vetting of Ahn Cheol-soo|newspaper=[[The Hankyoreh]]|date=12 October 2012|accessdate=18 April 2016}} Ahn was not an academic child but had number academic hobbies such as reading.http://entertain.naver.com/read?oid=109&aid=0002032901 He received his Doctor of Medicine (MD), Master of Science (MS), and Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) degrees in [[physiology]] from [[Seoul National University]] between 1980 and 1991. He became the youngest chief of professors at [[Dankook University]] medical college at 27 years of age, marking his first career as a medical doctor.{{Cite news|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2011/09/113_94248.html|title=Who is Ahn Cheol-soo|date=2011-09-05|work=koreatimes|access-date=2017-03-29|language=en}} Ahn met his wife whilst in university.{{Cite news|url=http://news.jkn.co.kr/article/news/20090618/3355840.htm|title=‘무릎팍도사’ 출연 안철수, “부인과는 유명한 캠퍼스 커플, 프러포즈는…”|last=재경일보|date=2009-06-18|work=재경일보|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} Whilst working as a graduate student pursuing his MD, Ahn began to gain an interest in computer software as a hobby, in particular, [[antivirus software]]. Ahn soon began working on his own antivirus software after he was confronted with a virus that was mass-infecting computers in Korea. Ahn was soon infected with the same virus and reverse engineered the virus in an attempt to erase it from his disk drive which was successful. The program he wrote to help get rid of the virus was eventually called "Vaccine"{{Cite web|url=http://www.newsen.com/news_view.php?uid=200906180048251001|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} which Ahn distributed for free. == Business Career == === AhnLab, Inc === After finishing military service as a medical officer in the [[Republic of Korea Navy|South Korean navy]], and leaving behind his career in the medical profession, Cheol-soo went on to establish his venture company [[AhnLab, Inc.|AhnLab, Inc]] in March 1995 after being advised by a software company official to do so.{{Cite news|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=102&oid=029&aid=0001985929|title=안철수 KAIST 교수, 17일 무릎팍 도사 출연|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} Ahn had previously attempted to distribute V3 via Samsung's brand though Samsung rejected Ahn's offer.{{Cite web|url=http://artsnews.mk.co.kr/news/29862|title=안철수, 1000만 불 인수제의 거절한 이유!! {{!}} 아츠뉴스|website=artsnews.mk.co.kr|access-date=2018-05-10}} Ahn, not knowing how to run a business at first, struggled for the first several years.{{Cite web|url=https://entertain.naver.com/read?oid=143&aid=0001993990|title=‘무릎팍도사’ 안철수, 반쪽짜리 감동|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Whilst managing the company, Ahn was also attempting to get a master's degree in engineering at the [[University of Pennsylvania]], where he graduated in 1997.{{Cite web|url=http://news.hankooki.com/lpage/society/201103/h2011031821075622020.htm|title=|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Ahn eventually received a $10 million offer from US software giant, [[McAfee]]민도식, 나를 확바꾸는 실천 독서법 북포스 155페이지 '1997년 직원들에게 안철수연구소를 맡겨둔채 미국에서 유학하며 실리콘벨리에 머물던 중 현재 경쟁회사 맥아피에게 1천만달러 제안 받았지만 거절' and Ahn met with [[John McAfee]] personally. McAfee was struggling to expand into South Korea due to AhnLab, Inc and wanted to purchase the company in an attempt to monopolize the anti-virus software market in South Korea. Ahn rejected the offer because, despite the AhnLab, Inc struggling, selling the company would lead to widespread redundancies.{{Cite news|url=http://entertain.naver.com/read?oid=015&aid=0002085972|title='무릎팍도사' 출연 안철수, 온화한 카리스마로 시청자 압도|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.hkn24.com/news/articleView.html?idxno=27942|title=무릎팍 안철수 “외국회사 1000만불 매각제의 단호히 거절” - 헬스코리아뉴스|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} In 1999, the company began to run a surplus after the CIH virus became widespread in Korea and people needed to buy V3 to protect against it.{{Cite news|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=101&oid=047&aid=0001963116|title=안철수 "정치할 생각 있냐고요?"|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} By the end of 1999, AhnLab, Inc became the second biggest computer security company in South Korea.{{Cite news|url=http://www.asiatoday.co.kr/view.php?key=258456|title=‘무릎팍도사’ 출연 안철수, “한국의 빌게이츠(?)...너무 과분해”|work=종합일간지 : 신문/웹/모바일 등 멀티 채널로 국내외 실시간 뉴스와 수준 높은 정보를 제공|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} The same company later became the largest computer security company in South Korea,[https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/biz/2009/10/258_40800.html ''AhnLab Looks to Perform in International Stage''] at ''[[The Korea Times|Korea Times]]''.[http://www.koreaittimes.com/story/5502/ahnlab-considers-overseas-ma ''AhnLab Considers Overseas M&A''] at ''Korea IT Times''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/20/world/asia/new-voice-in-south-korean-politics-enters-presidential-race.html|title=New Voice in South Korean Politics, Ahn Cheol-soo, Enters Presidential Race|last=Gladstone|first=Rick|date=2012-09-19|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-03-29|last2=Lee|first2=Su-hyun|issn=0362-4331}} and was included in annual lists of Korea's most admired companies by Korea Management Association Consulting between 2004 and 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.kmac.co.kr/certify/certify_01a_1.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-08-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304024034/http://www.kmac.co.kr/certify/certify_01a_1.asp |archivedate=2016-03-04 }} {{ko icon}}[http://www.asiae.co.kr/uhtml/read.php?idxno=2008022017371847343 ''AhnLab, "The Korea's Most Admired company" Consecutive 5 years''] at ''Asia Economy'' (2008.02.20). {{ko icon}}{{Cite web|url=http://kr.ahnlab.com/company/eng/about/milestone.jsp|title=AhnLab|date=|publisher=Kr.ahnlab.com|accessdate=2010-01-22}}[http://news.mk.co.kr/outside/view.php?year=2008&no=92321 ''Samsung Electronics Most Admired Company in Korea: Survey''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723173328/http://news.mk.co.kr/outside/view.php?year=2008&no=92321 |date=23 July 2011 }} at ''Maeil Business Newspaper'' & mk.co.kr[http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/culture/book/297104.html Book review "''세상에서 가장 안전한 이름 안철수 연구소''"] at ''[[The Hankyoreh]]''. {{ko icon}} He resigned as CEO in 2005 and served as chairman of the board until 2012. Ahn revealed that [[John McAfee]] once suggested it would acquire AhnLab for $10,000,000 but rejected the offer. He mentioned patriotic reasons about the decision saying that selling AhnLab might allow a foreign firm to dominate the Korean market. === Later life and education === Ahn became an outside director of [[POSCO]] in 2005, and from 2010 to 2011 was chairman of the company. Ahn was awarded an Executive Master of Business Administration (EMBA) degree from the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania|Wharton School]] (San Francisco campus) in 2008. He then became a professor at [[KAIST]] in 2008, and later in the beginning of 2011 became the Dean of the Graduate School of Convergence Science and Technology at [[Seoul National University]]. ==Political career== ===Entry into politics === Since 2006, Ahn had been offered places in the main political parties but was constantly denied any chance to run as an independent due to opposing factions. In early September 2011, speculation spread that Ahn would enter politics by competing in the 26 October Seoul mayoral by-election. The Democratic Party and Liberty Korea Party attempted to recruit Ahn for the mayoral by-election though they failed due to Ahn feeling like he, and many other voters, had become disenfranchised with the main two choices.{{Cite web|url=http://www.imbc.com/broad/tv/culture/sisa2580/vod/index.html?kind=image&progCode=1000845100520100000&pagesize=5&pagenum=1&cornerFlag=1&ContentTypeID=1&ProgramGroupID=0|title=다시보기 {{!}} 시사매거진 2580|website=www.imbc.com|language=ko|access-date=2018-05-10}} Ahn eventually made an announcement, denouncing the opposition and ruling party{{Cite web|url=http://news.nate.com/view/20110905n06506|title=안철수, "야권과 단일화 얼마든지 고려할 수 있다"|website=네이트뉴스|language=ko-KR|access-date=2018-05-10}} and saying he was not sure on his candidacy, deciding to watch the polls before making a choice though he shared the sentiment that he felt like it'd take a lot of work to help Seoul, saying "ten years of work" would be needed to help the city.{{Cite web|url=http://news.nate.com/view/20110905n07503|title=안철수 "윤여준이 기획자? 그건 언론의 오보"|website=네이트뉴스|language=ko-KR|access-date=2018-05-10}} Analysts stated that if positioned as an independent, Ahn would attract a degree of support from those disaffected by mainstream political parties in the wake of corruption allegations and continuing policy failures. Ahn's polling was higher than other potential candidates, at 35% with second place coming in at 17%.{{Cite web|url=http://news.nate.com/view/20110905n02597|title=안철수, 서울시장 보선 여론조사서 압도적 선두|website=네이트뉴스|language=ko-KR|access-date=2018-05-10}} His approval rating was subsequently polled afterwards, reaching over 50%.{{Cite news|url=http://www.mediatoday.co.kr/news/articleView.html?idxno=97232|title=조국 "안철수에 큰박수" 진중권 "과연 인물"|last=미디어오늘|date=2011-09-06|work=미디어오늘|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} Ahn eventually didn't run despite his positive poll ratings{{Cite news|url=http://v.media.daum.net/v/20110907084056110|title="아무 조건 없습니다" 안철수 깨끗한 양보|date=2011-09-07|work=다음 뉴스|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} instead endorsing [[Park Won-soon]] who went on to win the by-election.{{Cite news|url=http://v.media.daum.net/v/20110907024716274|title=박원순, 안철수 지지율 흡수 여부가 변수|date=2011-09-07|work=다음 뉴스|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} Park's win has been attributed to Ahn's endorsement due to centrist voters moving to Park's side after the endorsement.{{Cite news|url=http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=032&aid=0002162450|title=박원순 ‘안철수 지지’ 업고 나경원과 오차내 접전|access-date=2018-05-10|language=ko}} He alluded to standing as a presidential candidate in his 2012 book ''Thoughts of Ahn Cheol-Soo''.{{cite news|last=Yeong-doo|first=Kang|title=Ahn Cheol-soo to announce his candidancy virtually|url=http://www.yonhapnews.co.kr/politics/2012/07/19/0502000000AKR20120719102051001.HTML?template=5565|accessdate=19 July 2012 |newspaper=Yonhapnews |date=19 July 2012}} ===First presidential campaign (2012)=== On 19 September 2012, at 3 p.m. [[Korea Standard Time]], Ahn held a press conference and announced his intention to run for the [[South Korean presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]]. This announcement came after months of speculation on whether or not Ahn was going to run for the presidency. The South Korean presidential election was to be held on 19 December 2012. In an address that lasted around 20 minutes, Ahn spent a considerable amount of time explaining how he came to the decision to run for President of the Republic of Korea, quoting the people he had met while exploring his candidacy, who had expressed their desire for a "new politics". Ahn at one point showed to be polling stronger than [[Moon Jae-in]], with a few polls showing he could win against [[Park Geun-hye]], the candidate who would go on to win the election. On 23 November 2012, at 8:20 p.m. KST, Ahn announced that he would drop out of the race,http://news.naver.com/main/president2012/news/read.nhn?mid=hot&sid1=154&cid=909465&iid=39207146&oid=003&aid=0004843794&ptype=011 endorsing Moon Jae-in, the Democratic United Party presidential candidate. ===Early Assembly career (2013–2016)=== On 11 March 2013, Ahn announced that he would run for a seat in the [[National Assembly of South Korea]] as an independent candidate in the by-election in the district of [[Seoul]] [[Nowon-gu|Nowon]] C. He won the election on 24 April, entering his first elected office.{{cite news|title=전국 12개 재보선 개표 마무리…安·金·李 당선|url=http://news1.kr/articles/1105911|accessdate=24 April 2013|newspaper=News1}} In May 2013, he launched a new think tank named Policy Network Tomorrow.{{cite news|title=안철수 싱크탱크 출범, 신당 창당 궤도에 올라|url=http://www.newdaily.co.kr/news/article.html?no=155844|accessdate=25 May 2013|newspaper=Newdaily}} ==== New Politics Alliance for Democracy Chairmanship (2014) ==== Having entered the Assembly, Ahn began to explore the creation of a new party, which was provisionally named the New Political Vision Party on the basis of public surveys.{{cite news|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2985037|title=Ahn’s party to establish new name at gathering|newspaper=[[Korea JoongAng Daily]]|date=17 February 2014|accessdate=15 April 2016}} On 26 March 2014, however, while the party was in the process of being set up, Ahn merged his faction with the liberal Democratic Party to form the [[New Politics Alliance for Democracy]] (NPAD), becoming co-chairman of the new party alongside [[Kim Han-gil]].{{cite news|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/Article.aspx?aid=2985728|title=Political shocker as DP, Ahn Cheol-soo merge|newspaper=[[Korea JoongAng Daily]]|date=3 March 2014|accessdate=15 April 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://english.donga.com/List/3/all/26/407931/1|title=Democratic Party, Ahn Cheol-soo agree to create new party|newspaper=[[The Dong-A Ilbo]]|date=3 March 2014|accessdate=15 April 2016}} Ahn and Kim both resigned from their position three months later in July following the new party's disappointing performance in [[South Korean by-elections, 2014|by-elections that year]], which had seen the liberals lose a seat in [[Jeolla]] to conservatives for the first time in 26 years.{{cite news|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=2992867|title=Co-chairmen quit amid election rubble|newspaper=[[Korea JoongAng Daily]]|date=1 August 2014|accessdate=15 April 2016}} ==== Defection from the NPAD (2015) ==== Ahn remained in the NPAD, but came into increasing conflict with Moon Jae-in, who had taken over sole leadership of the party after his resignation, and the "pro-Roh" faction that Moon represented. In December 2015, Ahn issued an ultimatum to Moon demanding that a convention be held at the beginning of 2016 to elect a new party leader. Moon rejected the demand.{{cite news|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/Article.aspx?aid=3012565|title=NPAD’s Moon rejects Ahn demand|newspaper=[[Korea JoongAng Daily]]|date=9 December 2015|accessdate=15 April 2016}} Ahn then left the NPAD along with a range of other lawmakers opposed to Moon, including Kim Han-gil.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2015/12/116_193056.html|title=Ahn Cheol-soo calls it quits with NPAD|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=13 December 2015|accessdate=15 April 2016}} Announcing that he would form a new party, he subsequently joined forces with [[Chun Jung-bae]], who had left the party earlier in the year,{{cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20150914001156|title=Party feud erodes Moon’s leadership|newspaper=[[The Korea Herald]]|date=14 September 2015|accessdate=12 April 2016}} to form the [[People's Party (South Korea, 2016)|People's Party]] in January 2016.{{cite news|url=http://tbsefm.seoul.kr/eNews/news.do?method=efmNewsInfo&idx_800=2143018&typ_800=N |title=Ahn Cheol-Soo, Chun Jung-Bae To Create New Party |publisher=TBS eFM |date=25 January 2016 |accessdate=12 April 2016}}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Moon resigned as leader after Ahn's defection, describing his experience as "a series of difficult days without a single one of respite".{{cite news|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/728307.html|title=Moon Jae-in steps down as leader of The Minjoo Party of Korea|newspaper=[[The Hankyoreh]]|date=28 January 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} ===People's Party (2016–2018)=== Ahn positioned the new [[People's Party (South Korea, 2016)|People's Party]] as an anti-establishment centrist force, attracting support from both political wings.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/04/116_201981.html|title=Ahn's popularity baffles parties|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=5 April 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} He labeled the remaining NPAD "anachronistic progressives",{{cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20160118000971|title=Debate over first President Rhee reignites|newspaper=[[The Korea Herald]]|date=18 January 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} and accused contemporary Korean politicians of lacking policies beyond "short-term gimmicks".{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/emanuel-pastreich/the-bernie-sanders-of-kor_b_9211944.html|title=The Bernie Sanders of Korea? An Interview With Ahn Cheol-soo|newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]]|date=11 February 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} In the lead-up to the [[South Korean legislative election, 2016|April 13 parliamentary election]], he came into conflict with his co-leader Chun and other members of the party after [[Kim Chong-in]], the interim leader of the Democratic Party, the NPAD's successor, called for the two parties to form an electoral alliance. Kim Han-gil and Ahn's co-leader Chun both supported the plan, but Ahn rejected any prospect of an alliance with his former party.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/03/116_199827.html|title=Ahn stumbling on internal feud|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=7 March 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} The proposal was ultimately scotched, with Kim Han-gil withdrawing from the upcoming election in protest.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/03/116_200609.html |title=Rep. Kim not to run in April elections |newspaper=[[The Korea Times]] |date=17 March 2016 |accessdate=15 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424133619/http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/03/116_200609.html |archivedate=24 April 2016 |df= }} In the event, the People's Party performed better than anticipated, coming second in [[party-list proportional representation|party-list]] voting and winning 38 seats overall, including 23 of the 28 districts in the liberal stronghold of Jeolla.{{cite news|url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/739721.html|title=In liberal stronghold, voters give main opposition party a lashing|newspaper=[[The Hankyoreh]]|date=14 April 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} The People's Party held the balance of power in the new Assembly, establishing a [[multi-party system|three-party system]].{{cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20160413000614|title=Minority People's Party steals show: Ahn’s Party holds balance of power as three party system dawns|newspaper=[[The Korea Herald]]|date=14 April 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} Ahn was credited for the victory, which was seen as giving him a position as [[kingmaker]] and support for contesting [[South Korean presidential election, 2017|the presidential elections in the following year]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-14/software-tycoon-turns-political-kingmaker-in-korean-stalemate|title=Software Tycoon Turns Political Kingmaker in Korea Stalemate|publisher=[[Bloomberg News|Bloomberg]]|date=14 April 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}}{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/04/116_202545.html|title=Attention to shift to 2017 presidential race|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=13 April 2016|accessdate=15 April 2016}} Following the election, Ahn rejected continued calls to regroup with the Minjoo Party, stating that "it would be inappropriate to speak of politically realigning at this point in time". He added that the People's Party would not be "a mere tie-breaking third party, but ... a new opinion leader in parliamentary affairs".{{cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20160417000276|title=Ahn gestures at moving onto presidential race|newspaper=[[The Korea Herald]]|date=17 April 2016|accessdate=18 April 2016}} ==== Second presidential campaign and defeat (2017) ==== Ahn was widely known to be a likely contender for the [[South Korean presidential election, 2017|2017 South Korean presidential election]]. He was selected as the People's Party's nominee,{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/14/world/asia/south-korea-election-ahn-cheol-soo.html|title=South Korea Election Turns Into 2-Way Race as Dark Horse Surges|last=Sang-hun|first=Choe|date=2017-04-14|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-04-15|issn=0362-4331}} defeating [[Sohn Hak-kyu]] and [[Park Joo-sun]].http://news.naver.com/main/read.nhn?mode=LSD&mid=sec&sid1=100&oid=079&aid=0003072580 Despite rapid increase in opinion polling which briefly bypassed [[Moon Jae-in|Moon Jae-In]], Ahn floundered in TV debates that led to his loss finishing third in a field of five total candidates.'{{Cite news|url=http://www.ytn.co.kr/_ln/0101_201705032206263984|title=Ahn And Hong Exchanges 2nd Place In Polling}} ==== Return of party chairmanship (2017-2018) ==== The underperformance of his presidential campaign and a party scandal that found People's Party members fabricating evidence to smear Moon Jae-in's campaign led Ahn to declare in July 2017 to both apologize and take a step back from politics in "self-reflection." He returned a month later to run, and later win, the party chairmanship.{{Cite web|url=http://mengnews.joins.com/view.aspx?aId=3037660|title=Ahn Cheol-soo hails his comeback as People’s Party head|website=Korea JoongAng Daily|access-date=2017-09-15}} === Bareunmirae Party (2018-present) === As head of the People's Party, Ahn was a strong advocate for merging with the center-right Bareun Party. The two leaders of the respective parties, Ahn and former presidential contender [[Yoo Seong-min|Yoo Seung-min]], pushed forward with the merger which was completed in February 2018. Although Yoo retained a leadership position within the new party and Ahn stepped down from any leadership role, as of March 2018 took on the role of leading the party's talent recruiting committee - a formal position speculated to signal his preparation to run for the Seoul mayorship later in the year.{{Cite news|url=http://www.koreaherald.com/view.php?ud=20180316000791|title=Parties ready for Seoul mayoral election|last=Herald|first=The Korea|date=2018-03-16|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en}} ==== Seoul Mayorship campaign (2018) ==== ==Political positions== === "New Politics" === Ahn has stated that he considers [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] to be a role model, and has referred to himself as the [[Bernie Sanders]] of Korea.{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/emanuel-pastreich/the-bernie-sanders-of-kor_b_9211944.html|title=The Bernie Sanders of Korea? An Interview With Ahn Cheol-soo|newspaper=The World Post|date=11 February 2016|accessdate=17 February 2016}} He supports an increased [[capital gains tax]], higher public welfare spending, and a cautious approach to free trade agreements. === Centrism === Ahn has also made appeals to conservatives, however, and has associated the People's Party with "reformative" currents of Korean conservatism.{{cite news|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2016/04/116_202138.html|title=Ahn backs Yoo to woo conservatives|newspaper=[[The Korea Times]]|date=7 April 2016|accessdate=14 April 2016}} In September 2012, Ahn visited the graves of [[Syngman Rhee]], [[Park Chung-hee]], and [[Kim Dae-jung]]. Park and Rhee are often praised by Korean conservatives, and Kim by liberals. Ahn stated at the time that it would be "hypocritical to paint half the people as enemies and at the same time call for 'unity{{'"}}.{{cite news|url=http://www.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/552749.html|title=Ahn visits National Cemetery in first political act|newspaper=[[The Hankyoreh]]|date=21 September 2012|accessdate=17 April 2016}} Ahn has been considered "more palatable for conservative voters" in part due to his business background. === National security (THAAD) === Ahn was among the first who opposed the American deployment of the [[Terminal High Altitude Area Defense]] system, commonly referred to as THAAD, alongside Moon Jae-in. However, he changed his stance suggesting it was "irresponsible" for any future president to reverse an agreement already made between the United States and Korea. === LGBT rights === Ahn has stated he opposes the legalization of [[same-sex marriage]], although in a more detailed article on broadcasting network SBS' website, he said that same-sex marriage needs to be achieved through social discussion.{{cn|date=February 2018}} ==Philanthropy== In December 2011, Ahn has expressed his willingness to donate half of his shares in AhnLab for the education of children from low-income families. He owns 37.1 percent of AhnLab shares, and as of 9 December 2011, the value of the shares to be donated is about 250 billion won ($218 million).{{cite news |first = Gwang-bin (광빈) |last = Lee (이) |script-title=ko:안철수 기부주식 2천500억원 넘어 |date = 2011-12-11 |url = http://www.yonhapnews.co.kr/bulletin/2011/12/10/0200000000AKR20111210045600001.HTML |work = Yonhap News |accessdate = 2011-12-11 |language = Korean}} ==Legal problems== In September 2012, Ahn made a public apology as reports surfaced that his wife evaded taxes by under-pricing a 2001 apartment she bought worth ₩450 million to ₩250 million, thus reducing the acquisition and registration taxes by up to ₩10 million. However, a statement by the Korea Taxpayers' Association claimed that the "down contract" was in accordance with trade customs and thus not unlawful due to flaws in the local tax law between 1996 and 2005.{{Cite news |last=Bae |first=Hyun-jung |title=Ahn apologizes for wife's tax-dodging |newspaper=Korea Herald |publication-place=Seoul |date=28 September 2012 |ref=harv |postscript= }} == Personal life == In 1988 he married Kim Mi-kyung, who is currently a professor at the Seoul National University College of Medicine. Ahn has a daughter with Kim.http://news.mk.co.kr/newsRead.php?year=2012&no=610838 {{ko icon}} ==Bibliography== * 2012. '''Anton Vyacheslavovich Krasovsky''' ({{lang-ru|Антóн Вячеслáвович Красóвский}}) (born 18 July 1975) is a Russian political journalist, television personality and gay rights activist.{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}}
==Life and career== Krasovsky was born on 18 July 1975 in [[Podolsk]] and studied at the [[Maxim Gorky Literature Institute]].<ref name="snob1"/> In 2011 Krasovsky participated in the presidential campaign of [[Mikhail Prokhorov]].<ref name="Prokhorov's campaign to be run by journalist Anton Krasovsky"/> He also worked as a journalist and editor at the pro-[[Kremlin]]{{fact|date=March 2014}} [[NTV (Russia)|NTV]] channel.<ref name=wc/> He also worked at ''[[Kommersant]]'', ''[[Yandex]]'', ''[[Nezavisimaya Gazeta]]'' and ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'', and other publications.<ref name="Following Paul Pubic NTV went with Anton Krasovsky"/>
Krasovsky later began work at another pro-Kremlin{{fact|date=March 2014}} channel, [[Kontr TV]], started by himself and [[Sergey Minaev]] in December 2012.<ref name=snob/> On 25 January 2013, during a discussion of a proposed national [[LGBT rights in Russia#Bans on "homosexual propaganda"|ban on "homosexual propaganda"]], Krasovsky revealed his homosexuality, stating on-air, "I'm gay and I'm as much a human-being as Putin and Medvedev." ({{lang-ru|Я гей и такой же человек, как Путин и Медведев.|links=no}})<ref name=snob/> His statement was not made available online or was deleted soon afterwards,<ref name=wc/><ref name=dm/><ref name=huffingtonpost/> and on 28 January Krasovsky resigned from the channel and denounced the working environment there.<ref name="snob"/><ref name="lenta"/> According to other sources, he was fired the same day.<ref name="Russian anchor fired after coming out on live TV"/> His face was soon censored from the show website and removed from the TV show's archives.<ref name=huffingtonpost/>
Krasovsky stated that he came out because he had enough feeling like a hypocrite.<ref name=snob/> He later referred to the channel's entire output as "propaganda."<ref name="snob2"/> In May, following the murder of [[Vlad Tornovy]] reportedly because he was thought to be gay,<ref name="Arrests over 'anti-gay' murder in Volgograd Russia"/> Krasovsky published an article in ''The Guardian'' denouncing homophobia in Russia. He wrote:<ref name="I came out because gay people in Russia are suffering – it's time for courage"/> {{quote|How did it come about that today in Russia a good gay person is a dead gay person? How did there come to be a law in the Duma that forbids justifying homosexuality? Until now, the only thing you were forbidden to justify in my country was terrorism.... So as far as the deputies are concerned I am not a human being in the same sense that they are; I am to be classed as scum, like a terrorist. As far as the deputies are concerned I am scum by the fact of my birth, and it was criminal negligence not to have made a note of that in my birth certificate. What seemed like a bad dream only a couple of years ago has now become reality. And it is terrifying to imagine what could happen tomorrow.}}
Krasovsky spoke out in August 2013 against the [[Concerns and controversies at the 2014 Winter Olympics#Pride House and LGBT rights|boycott of the 2014 Winter Olympics]] in Russia that some gay rights activists proposed. He said: "If you want to boycott Olympic games in Russia, you're trying to boycott 7 million gay people in Russia. You want to boycott me."<ref name=huffingtonpost/> He is interviewed about his experiences in the 2014 documentary film ''[[Campaign of Hate: Russia and Gay Propaganda]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.out.com/entertainment/movies/2014/05/16/russia-deadly-campaign|title=Russia's Deadly Campaign|author=<!-- Staff -->|work=[[Out (magazine)|Out]]|date=2014-05-16|accessdate=2015-04-08}}</ref>
In July 2016, Anton Krasovsky and the head of the outpatient department of the Moscow Regional AIDS Center Elena Orlova-Morozova established The Foundation in support of people who live with HIV — [[AIDS.Center]].<ref name="newizv2016">{{cite web |url= https://newizv.ru/news/society/06-10-2016/247659-zachem-nam-vashi-dengi-fond-spidcentr-prosit-o-pomoshi |title=Фонд «СПИД.ЦЕНТР» просит о финансовой помощи |trans-title = AIDS.Center Foundation asks for financial help |author= Yesenia Martynova |date=2016-10-06 |publisher= New Izvestia | language = Russian |accessdate=2018-04-15}}</ref>
In December 2017, Krasovsky revealed that he has been HIV positive since 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://iz.ru/679211/2017-12-05/zhurnalist-anton-krasovskii-rasskazal-o-svoem-polozhitelnom-vich-statuse|title=Журналист Антон Красовский рассказал о своем положительном ВИЧ-статусе|language=ru|work=[[Izvestia]]|date=2017-12-05|accessdate=2017-12-05}}</ref>

[[Image:2008 03 Bonnie Woods at Tottenham Court Road.jpg|thumb|right|Bonnie Woods was [[Suppressive Person|declared Suppressive]] and subjected to a smear campaign.]]
'''Bonnie Woods''' is an [[United States|American]] former [[Scientology|Scientologist]] and critic of the [[Church of Scientology]]. Woods resides in [[United Kingdom|Britain]]. She was a member of the [[Sea Org]] within Scientology, and left in 1982. She and her family were monitored by a private investigator. The Church of Scientology spread pamphlets around her [[East Grinstead]] neighbourhood making negative claims about her. Woods sued for [[libel]] against the organization – in response Scientology filed three libel suits against her. Her case eventually reached the [[High Court of Justice]]. Scientology paid her for costs and damages, and admitted that the claims it had made about her were false.
==Scientology==
===Leaving the organization=== An American who moved to Britain, Bonnie Woods had been a member of the [[Sea Organization]] but left Scientology in 1982.<ref name="indep_hate" /> Since 1992, she and her husband Richard have run a telephone helpline for families affected by Scientology.<ref name="american" /> Scientologists declared her a "[[Suppressive Person]]", picketing her house and around [[East Grinstead]] and putting her family under surveillance.<ref name="american" /> She and her family were followed by a private investigator,<ref name="escaperoute" /> and a creditor of theirs was located and provided free legal assistance to sue them.<ref name="hounded" /> Woods told a local paper, "The biggest concern I have is for my children. Obviously I worry about their safety. I can never let them answer the phone or the door."<ref name="escaperoute">{{cite news|work=[[East Grinstead Courier]] |publisher= |title=Escape route from Scientology has never been busier |date=April 15, 1994 }}</ref> Private investigator Eugene Ingram persuaded a creditor of Richard Woods' failed building firm to accept free help from Scientologists to pursue her money.<ref name="hounded" /> As a result, the family was bankrupted.<ref name="american">{{cite news|title=Scientology's Campaign Of Hate, By "Cult Busters"|work=[[The American (magazine)|The American]]|date=6 March 1998|last=Nicolova|first=Rossitsa|page=5}}</ref><ref name="hounded">{{cite news|title=Hounded by the church of stars and hype|work=[[Sunday Times]]|publisher=[[Times Newspapers]]|date=January 1, 1997|last=Driscoll|first=Margarette|author2=Steven Haynes| page=10}}</ref><ref name="argus_inside">{{cite news|first=David |last=Edwards|title=Inside The Scientologists|work=[[The Argus (Brighton)|The Argus]] |location=Brighton |date=May 12, 2000}}</ref>
===Libel litigation=== The Church spread leaflets calling her a "hate campaigner" around her [[East Grinstead]] neighbourhood and on the High Street.<ref name="american" /><ref>{{cite news|work=[[The Times]]|date=June 9, 1999|title=Scientologists pay £155,000 for 'hate' claim|last=Steiner|first=Susie|page=6}}</ref> Woods sued for libel, and in response the Church took out three libel suits against her.<ref name="american" /> In 1999, after six years of litigation, eventually reaching the [[High Court of Justice|High Court]], the Church of Scientology admitted that the claims were untrue and paid damages and costs.<ref>{{cite news|title=Scientologists pay for libel|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=June 9, 1999|page=11|last=Dyer|first=Clare|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/1999/jun/09/claredyer |accessdate=2008-05-03}}</ref><ref name="hatecampaign">{{cite news|work=[[Daily Mail]] |publisher= |title=Cult pays £155,000 over hate campaign |date=June 9, 1999 |page=32}}</ref> She told journalists that during the case she had been subjected to a "level of harassment that most people would find intolerable".<ref name="indep_hate">{{cite news|work=[[The Independent]]|title=Woman accused of hate campaign wins damages from Scientologists|date=June 9, 1999|last=Davison|first=John|publisher=Independent News and Media|page=14}}</ref><ref name="woods_express">{{cite news|title=My victory joy after six year battle with cult|work=[[The Express]]|publisher=Northern and Shell Media Publications|date=June 9, 1999|last=Palmer|first=Richard|page=19}}</ref>

{{BLP sources|date=May 2010}} '''Brian St. Clair''' (born May 24, 1968) is an [[United States|American]] drummer, best known for being with rock duo [[Local H]], from July 1999 until October 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p141542/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Biography: Local H|last=Rivadavia|first=Eduardo |publisher=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=1 May 2010}}</ref>
Raised in [[Fullerton, California]], Brian's family moved to the town of [[Glen Ellyn, Illinois]] in 1980.
He has played drums for a few Chicago area bands (in order): Eye's On Troy, Political Justice?, Denied Remarks (as a second drummer), God's Acre, [[My Life With The Thrill Kill Kult]], Rights Of The Accused (also known as: ROTA, the entire band sang back up vocals on a [[1000 Homo Djs]] record), and [[Triple Fast Action]]. Brian moved to NYC in 1998 after [[Triple Fast Action]] broke up.
After Political Justice? broke up St. Clair played with a few bands before landing the roll of drummer in one of Chicago's most famous punk bands Rights Of The Accused. In 1988 ROTA were taken on tour with [[Ministry (band)]] and became close friends with [[Al Jourgensen]] who took them into the studio to sing back up vocals on the [[1000 Homo DJs]] record and put the band in his video for the song Stigmata from the album ''[[The Land of Rape and Honey]]'' where St. Clair played drums, Herb played bass, Wes played guitar, and Mike jumped around and yelled. However it is very hard to see anyone other than Mike due to all of the fog produced by the fog machine on the set. Also while in ROTA Brian was cast by [[Cynthia Plaster Caster]], one of the Plaster Casters Of Chicago.
Kidd and St. Clair formed [[Triple Fast Action]] who released several singles on indie labels and a full CD on [[Capitol Records]] and one on [[Deep Elm]] records before Brian left the band to pursue other interests. In 1999 St. Clair joined [[Local H]] with [[Scott Lucas (musician)|Scott Lucas]].
Just prior to [[Local H]] he was the drum tech for [[Bun E. Carlos]] of [[Cheap Trick]], and was credited on Cheap Trick's Silver DVD. Brian has been the [[tour manager]] for [[Liz Phair]], [[Brazilian Girls]], [[Micki Free]], [[Triple Fast Action]], and [[Local H]]. He has also been dubbed one of the "hardest working drummers" in rock history.
St. Clair's hobbies include [[birdwatching]], in which he has seen 550 of the some 810 species in The USA. He was featured in a famous birdwatching book called "Red-Tails in Love" (Random House, 1998) by [[Marie Winn]]. In 1998 Brian St. Clair auditioned for the world famous "[[Blue Man Group]]" and was told to start taking acting classes so he could join in the future, he took three months of classes at T. Schriber acting school then got too busy with Cheap Trick to continue.
Aside from Local H, St. Clair works for three other bands: [[Cheap Trick]], [[Brazilian Girls]], and [[Micki Free]], where he works behind the scenes in Tour Management and production.
In December 2011 St. Clair signed a drum endorsement deal with Taye Drums.
On August 21, 2013 he announced that he would be departing from Local H after a farewell tour to focus on his tour management company.
In May 2014 he was diagnosed with [[prostate cancer]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6099254/former-local-h-drummer-brian-st-clair-diagnosed-with-prostate-cancer | title=Former Local H Drummer Brian St. Clair Diagnosed with Prostate Cancer | work=Billboard | date=24 May 2014 | accessdate=27 May 2014 | author=Staff}}</ref> As of April 2015, St. Clair is on indefinite [[hormonal therapy (oncology)|hormonal therapy]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://sweetrelief.org/program/brian-st-clair-fund/ |title=Brian St. Clair Fund - Sweet Relief |date=2015 |website=Sweet Relief |language=en-US |access-date=2017-09-14}}</ref>

'''Christian Moueix''' ({{IPA-fr|mu.ɛks|lang}}; born 1946) is a French [[winemaker]] and the president of the ''[[négociant]]'' house [[Établissements Jean-Pierre Moueix]] in [[Libourne]], overseeing production in several estates in [[Saint-Émilion AOC|Saint-Émilion]] and [[Pomerol]] including [[Château Pétrus]] and [[Château Trotanoy]]. He has managed the company since his father [[Jean-Pierre Moueix]] stepped down in 1978.<ref name=SAC>{{cite news|last =Murphy |first =Linda ''San Francisco Chronicle'' |title = MoueiX Files |url= http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2005/02/03/WIG0MB2BFC1.DTL |date =February 3, 2005 |work=The San Francisco Chronicle}}</ref>
==Early life== Christian Moueix was born in 1946,<ref name="decanter1">{{cite web|url=http://www.decanter.com/interviews/decanter-interview-christian-moueix-1338/ |title=interview: Christian Moueix |publisher=Decanter |date=2015-03-26 |accessdate=2017-03-24}}</ref> the son of [[Jean-Pierre Moueix]].
==Career== Moueix also owns [[Dominus Estate]] in [[Napa Valley AVA|Napa Valley, California]].<ref name=wro>{{cite web|last=Apstein|first=Michael, ''Wine Review Online''|title=A Conversation with Christian Moueix|url=http://www.winereviewonline.com/christian_moueix.cfm|date=August 30, 2005|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080406143515/http://www.winereviewonline.com/christian_moueix.cfm|archivedate=April 6, 2008|df=}}</ref> Upon a recommendation by [[Robert Mondavi]] to establish production in Napa Valley, Moueix entered into a partnership with Robin Lail and Marcia Smith in 1982 on the historic Napanook Vineyards estate<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|last =Prial |first =Frank J. ''The New York Times'' |title =Wine Talk |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1988/03/09/garden/wine-talk-703888.html?pagewanted=all |date =March 9, 1988 }}</ref> and became the sole owner of the property in 1995.<ref name=SAC/><ref name=wro2>{{cite web|last=Apstein|first=Michael, ''Wine Review Online''|title=A Conversation with Christian Moueix, Part II: Dominus Estate|url=http://www.winereviewonline.com/christian_moueix_part_2.cfm|date=September 27, 2005|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080226012041/http://www.winereviewonline.com/christian_moueix_part_2.cfm|archivedate=February 26, 2008|df=}}</ref>
In 2008, Moueix was chosen the "Man of the Year" by the wine magazine ''[[Decanter (magazine)|Decanter]]''.<ref name=moty08>{{cite web|last= Lechmere |first= Adam, ''Decanter.com'' |title= Moueix named Decanter Man of the Year |url=http://www.decanter.com/wine-news/moueix-named-decanter-man-of-the-year-83920/|date= March 4, 2008}}</ref>
==Personal life== Moueix is married to Cherise, and they have two children, Edouard, who has worked for JPM since about 2005, and Charlotte, a wildlife vet in South Africa.<ref name="decanter1"/>
==Art collectors== Moueix and his wife Cherise are well-known art collectors. In 2014, she sold [[Mark Rothko]]'s ''No. 6 (Violet, Green and Red)'' to [[Yves Bouvier]] through an intermediary for $80 million plus an unspecified commission, which Bouvier then sold to [[Dmitry Rybolovlev]] for €140 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-04-27/a-186-million-rothko-pits-russian-tycoon-against-art-merchant |title=A $186 Million Rothko Pits Russian Tycoon Against Art Merchant |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2017-03-24}}</ref>

'''David Meredith Reese''' (1800-1861) was an American [[physician]] and [[Skepticism|skeptic]].
Reese worked as a physician at the [[NYC Health + Hospitals/Bellevue|Bellevue Hospital]] until 1849.<ref>Kelly; Howard Atwood; Burrage, Walter Lincoln. (1920). ''American Medical Biographies''. Norman, Remington Company. p. 968</ref> He was a skeptical of the many "isms" of his day.<ref>Lewis, W. David. (2009). ''From Newgate to Dannemora: The Rise of the Penitentiary in New York, 1796-1848''. Fall Creek Books. p. 236. {{ISBN|978-0801475481}}</ref> He had heavily criticized [[quackery]] in his book ''Humbugs of New York'' (1838).<ref>Miller, Julie. (2008). ''Abandoned: Foundlings in Nineteenth-century New York City''. NYU Press. p. 103. {{ISBN|978-0814757260}}</ref> He was highly critical of [[phrenology]].<ref>Fabian, Ann. (2010). ''The Skull Collectors: Race, Science, and America's Unburied Dead''. University Of Chicago Press. p. 74. {{ISBN|978-0226233482}}</ref>
Reese's book was published several years before ''[[Extraordinary Popular Delusions and the Madness of Crowds]]'' (1841) and has been described as early [[Debunker|debunking]] work.<ref>Logan, Peter Melville. (2003). ''The Popularity of "Popular Delusions": Charles Mackay and Victorian Popular Culture''. Cultural Critique. No. 54. pp. 213-241 </ref><ref>Loxton, Daniel. (2013). [http://www.skeptic.com/downloads/Why-Is-There-a-Skeptical-Movement.pdf ''Why Is There a Skeptical Movement?'']. [[The Skeptics Society]]. Retrieved 18 April 2016.</ref>

{{Infobox person | name = Efrem Harkham | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place =[[Israel]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence =[[Beverly Hills, California]] | nationality =American | other_names = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation = Entrepreneur | title = | salary = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | children =3 | parents = | relatives =[[Uri Harkham]] | website = [http://LuxeHotels.com LuxeHotels.com] }} '''Efrem Harkham''' is an American hotelier and philanthropist from [[Beverly Hills, California]].
Harkham is the Founder and CEO of [http://LeHotels.com LeHotels.com], a company representing 200 hotels globally, and [http://LuxeHotels.com LuxeHotels.com], an entity consisting of three luxury hotels based in [[Beverly Hills, California]].
==Early life== Efrem Harkham was born in an [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish]] family in Israel.<ref name="latimes">Hugo Martin, [http://articles.latimes.com/2011/jul/10/business/la-fi-himi-harkham-20110710 Efrem Harkham oversees a world of hotels], ''[[The Los Angeles Times]]'', July 10, 2011</ref><ref name="jacquelinemaddison">Jacqueline Maddison, [http://www.beverlyhillsmagazine.com/business-leaders/spotlight-efrem-harkham/ Beverly Hills Spotlight: Efrem Harkham], ''Beverly Hills Magazine'', December 3, 2013</ref><ref name="naomi">Naomi Pfefferman, [http://www.jewishjournal.com/articles/item/labor_pains_19980220 Labor Pains], ''[[The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles]]'', February 19, 1998</ref> His maternal ancestors are keepers of [[Ezra's Tomb]] in Iraq.<ref name="lauracoleman">Laura Coleman, [http://bhcourier.com/luxe-celebrates-30-year-anniversary-real-estate-venture-global/ Luxe Celebrates 30-Year Anniversary; A Real Estate Venture That Went Global], ''[[The Beverly Hills Courier]]''</ref> However, he grew up in Australia.<ref name="latimes"/><ref name="naomi"/><ref name="tamaraaudi">Tamara Audi,[https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2014/11/04/in-los-angeles-some-voters-cast-ballots-in-luxury/ In Los Angeles, Some Voters Cast Ballots in Luxury ], ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', November 4, 2014</ref> He studied Law at university.<ref name="keithloria">Keith Loria, [http://www.csq.com/2013/09/efrem-harkham-the-luxe-factor/ Efrem Harkham: The Luxe Factor] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141205003922/http://www.csq.com/2013/09/efrem-harkham-the-luxe-factor/ |date=2014-12-05 }}, ''C-Suite Quarterly'', Q4 2013</ref> He has a brother, [[Uri Harkham]], the former President and Chief Executive Officer of Harkham Industries, a women's clothing company, Chairman Emeritus of Harkham Properties, and a Director of [[Public Storage]].<ref>[https://www.forbes.com/profile/uri-harkham/ Forbes: Uri Harkham]</ref><ref>[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=633762&privcapId=3585458 Bloomberg BusinessWeek: Uri Harkham]</ref>
==Career== Harkham started his career in the fashion industry.<ref name="jacquelinemaddison"/> He served as the Chief Executive Officer of Harkham Industries, representing the Jonathan Martin and Hype brands.<ref name="jacquelinemaddison"/> [[File:Luxe Rodeo Drive Hotel 2015.jpg|thumb|right|Luxe Rodeo Drive Hotel in Beverly Hills, California.]] He moved to Los Angeles in 1978.<ref name="jacquelinemaddison"/> Five years later, in 1983, he purchased the Bel-Air Summit Hotel, now known as the Luxe Sunset Boulevard Hotel, located in [[Bel Air, Los Angeles|Bel Air]].<ref name="latimes"/><ref name="naomi"/><ref name="luxehistory">[http://www.luxehotels.com/about/history Luxe Hotels: History]</ref> A decade later, in 1993, he purchased the [[Luxe Rodeo Drive Hotel]], located on [[Rodeo Drive]] in Beverly Hills.<ref name="latimes"/><ref name="lauracoleman"/> He subsequently added a third hotel to his portfolio, known as the Luxe City Center Hotel, located in [[Downtown Los Angeles]].<ref name="jacquelinemaddison"/> The three hotels comprise the Luxe Hotels brand.<ref name="latimes"/>
He founded Luxe Worldwide Hotels in 1998.<ref name="bloomberg">[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=10305478&privcapId=8969463 Bloomberg BusinessWeek]</ref> He serves as its President and Chief Executive Officer.<ref name="bloomberg"/> The company provides marketing, sales and reservation services to 200 hotels globally, with a workforce of 315 employees.<ref name="latimes"/>
He serves on the Board of Directors of the Jewish Television Network.<ref name="naomi"/>
==Philanthropy== In 1991, with his brother Uri, he donated $1 million to the Harkham Hillel Hebrew Academy.<ref name="naomi"/> With his ex-wife, he also donated to the 2008 renovation of the [[Shalhevet High School]], a co-education Orthodox Jewish school in Los Angeles.<ref>David Suissa, [http://www.jewishjournal.com/opinion/article/a_school_with_attitude_20080827 A school with attitude], ''The Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles'', August 27, 2008</ref> Additionally, he has donated to the [[Orthodox Union]] and [[Chabad]].<ref name="naomi"/>
He organizes the annual Apple Ball for the Beverly Hills Education Foundation.<ref name="keithloria"/>
==Personal life== He is a naturalized American citizen.<ref name="tamaraaudi"/> He was married to Kendra Harkham; they divorced in 2011.<ref name="markdavid">Mark David, [https://variety.com/2011/dirt/real-estalker/mary-mcdonald-sunburst-madness-in-beverly-hills-1201231607/ Mary McDonald Sunburst Madness in Beverly Hills], ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', June 8, 2011</ref> He resides in Beverly Hills, California.<ref name="keithloria"/>
