{{Infobox military person | name =Irma Grese | image=Irma Grese.jpg | caption = Irma Grese in August 1945, while awaiting trial | birth_date = 7 October 1923 | death_date = {{death date and age|df=y|1945|12|13|1923|10|7}} | birth_place = [[Feldberger Seenlandschaft|Wrechen]], [[Free State of Mecklenburg-Strelitz]], Germany | death_place = [[Hamelin]], Germany | nickname = ''The Beautiful Beast''
''Die Hyäne von Auschwitz''
("The Hyena of Auschwitz") | allegiance = {{flag|Nazi Germany}} | branch = [[File:Flag Schutzstaffel.svg|23px]] [[Schutzstaffel]] | serviceyears = 1942–1945 | rank = ''SS-Helferin'' | unit = {{unbulleted list|[[Ravensbrück concentration camp|Ravensbrück]]|[[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz]]|[[Bergen-Belsen concentration camp|Bergen-Belsen]]}} }} '''Irma Ida Ilse Grese''' (7 October 1923 – 13 December 1945) was a female ''[[SS]]'' guard at the [[Nazi concentration camp]]s of [[Ravensbrück concentration camp|Ravensbrück]] and [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz]], and served as warden of the women's section of [[Bergen-Belsen concentration camp|Bergen-Belsen]].[[The Times]]; ''The Belsen trial''; 18 September 1945; pg. 6 Grese was convicted for crimes involving the ill-treatment and murder of prisoners committed at Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen concentration camps, and sentenced to death at the [[Belsen trial]]. Executed at 22 years of age, Grese was the youngest woman to die judicially under British law in the 20th century. Auschwitz inmates nicknamed her the "Hyena of Auschwitz" ({{lang-de|die Hyäne von Auschwitz}}).{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kRswAQAAQBAJ&q=%22Hy%C3%A4ne+von+Auschwitz%22#v=snippet&q=%22Hy%C3%A4ne%20von%20Auschwitz%22&f=false|title=Vier Stückchen Brot: Ein Hymne an das Leben|publisher=Verlag|isbn=978-3641127091|date=2013|accessdate=4 January 2015|author=Magda Hollander-Lafon|pages=95{{ndash}}}}{{cite web|url=https://www.welt.de/kultur/literarischewelt/article131751631/Sie-waren-Moerderinnen-aus-Gelegenheit.html|title=Die Hyäne von Auschwitz|publisher=DIE WELT|website=Sie waren Mörderinnen aus Gelegenheit|date=30 August 2014|accessdate=4 January 2015|author=Barbara Möller}}{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/einestages/nazi-jaeger-hanns-alexander-auf-der-spur-von-rudolf-hoess-a-986892.html|title=Der Mann, der Rudolf Höß jagte|publisher=Spiegel Online, Hamburg, Germany|website=KZ-Aufseherin Irma Grese. Die "Hyäne von Auschwitz"|date=2014|accessdate=4 January 2015|author=Sonja Peteranderl}}{{cite web|url=http://www.weltwoche.ch/ausgaben/2013-41/hitlers-furien-die-weltwoche-ausgabe-412013.html|title=Hitlers Furien|publisher=Die Weltwoche Magazin|website=Grese, die «Hyäne von Auschwitz»|date=2013|accessdate=4 January 2015|author=Pierre Heumann}} ==Early life and family== Irma Ilse Ida Grese was born to Berta Grese and Alfred Grese, a dairy worker, on 7 October 1923. Irma was the third of five children (three girls and two boys). In 1936, her mother committed [[suicide]] by drinking [[hydrochloric acid]] after discovering that Alfred had had an affair with a local pub owner's daughter.[http://www.bergenbelsen.co.uk/pages/Staff/Staff.asp?CampStaffID=53 First Belsen Trial Oberaufseherin Irma Ilse Ida Grese], bergenbelsen.co.uk; accessed 8 April 2018. Historian [[Peter Vronsky]] speculated that Alfred Grese joined the [[Nazi Party]] in 1937{{cite book|title=Female Serial Killers: How and Why Women Become Monsters|first=Peter|last=Vronsky|url=https://books.google.com/?id=FdN0MMbGIQkC&pg=PA383&dq=irma+grese+when+she+1937#v=onepage&q=irma%20grese%20when%20she%201937&f=false|publisher=Penguin|year=2007|isbn=9781101205693}}{{cite web|url= http://blogboyerhistory.bloguez.com/blogboyerhistory/836238/Biographie_de_Irma_Grese_Gardienne_SS_a_AUSCHWITZ|title=Biographie de Irma Grese Gardienne SS à Auschwitz|date=18 December 2009|accessdate=1 March 2016|trans-title=Biography of Irma Grese, Guardian SS at Auschwitz|website=BlogBoyerHistory.Bloguez.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160302151957/http://blogboyerhistory.bloguez.com/blogboyerhistory/836238/Biographie_de_Irma_Grese_Gardienne_SS_a_AUSCHWITZ|archivedate=2 March 2016}} and remarried in 1939. Irma's sister, Helene Grese, noted at Irma's trial that in primary school, when "girls were quarreling and fighting, [Irma] never had the courage to fight, but… ran away."Kater, Michael H. ''Hitler Youth''. Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 2006, pg. 70. She left school in 1938 at age 15, probably due to a combination of a poor scholastic aptitude,{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} bullying by classmates,{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} and a [[fanaticism|fanatical]] preoccupation with the [[League of German Girls]] (''Bund Deutscher Mädel''), the Nazi female youth organization, of which her father disapproved.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} Among other casual jobs, she worked as an assistant nurse in the [[sanatorium]] of the SS for two years and unsuccessfully tried to find an apprenticeship as a nurse.{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}} ==Concentration camp guard== By the time she was a teen, Irma devoted herself to the Nazi cause and trained to become a nurse,{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} but after a series of failures,{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} she became obsessed with the [[Hitler Youth]] and the League of German Girls. By the time she was eighteen, she had moved to the SS Female Helpers’ training base, which was located near Ravensbrück, the all-female concentration camp. After her training, which stressed "the feminine ideal of nurturance",{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} she volunteered to work at Ravensbrück. {{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} She was soon promoted to a guard position at Auschwitz-Birkenau. From mid-1942 she was an ''[[Aufseherin]]'' (guard) at Ravensbrück, and in March 1943 she transferred to Auschwitz-Birkenau. In the second half of 1944 she was promoted to ''Rapportführerin'', the second-highest rank open to female KZ-wardens.{{cn|date=April 2018}} Soon after gaining power, she developed a reputation as a sadist.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} She was considered to be a nymphomaniac who slept with SS guards as well as prisoners—the latter{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}}, forcibly. She bribed young Jewish girls to stand watch for her as she raped other inmates, and, according to inmate and doctor [[Gisella Perl]], Grese "relished whipping well-developed young women on the breasts… Grese would eventually become sexually aroused just watching the women suffering."Sarti, Wendy Adele-Marie. ''Women and Nazis''. Bethesda: Academica Press, 2012. Author Wendy Adele-Marie Sarti wrote in her book ''Women and Nazis'' that she beat prisoners until their faces were completely raw, kicked them with her hobnailed jackboots until blood flowed, used her dog on the prisoners, forced men and women to hold rocks above their heads and kneel for hours at a time, and had a "whip which [she] used consistently whenever necessary." Grese participated in prisoner selections for the gas chambers at Auschwitz.{{cite book|title=Bergen-Belsen: Wehrmacht POW Camp 1940–1945, Concentration Camp 1943–1945, Displaced Persons Camp 1945–1950. Catalogue of the permanent exhibition|publisher=Wallstein|year=2010|isbn=978-3-8353-0794-0|editor-last=Knoch|editor-first=Habbo}}{{rp|219}} Prisoner [[Olga Lengyel]] wrote in her memoir ''[[Five Chimneys]]'' that selections in the women's camp were made by SS ''Aufseherin'' [[Elisabeth Hasse]] and Irma Grese (spelled ''Griese'' in Lengyel's account). The latter was visibly pleased by the terror her presence inspired in the women at roll call. Grese had a penchant for selecting not only the sick and the weak but any woman who had retained vestiges of her former beauty. Lengyel said Grese had several lovers among the SS in the camp, including [[Josef Mengele]]. After Grese forced the inmate surgeon at the infirmary into performing her illegal abortion, she disclosed that she planned a career in film acting after the war. Lengyel felt that Grese’s meticulous grooming, custom-fitted clothes and overuse of perfume were part of a deliberate act of sadism directed toward the ragged women prisoners.{{cite book|title=Five Chimneys|last=Lengyel|first=Olga|publisher=Academy Chicago|year=1995|isbn=978-0-89733-376-4}} In early 1945, Grese accompanied a prisoner evacuation transport from Auschwitz to Ravensbrück. In March 1945, she went to Bergen-Belsen along with a large number of prisoners from Ravensbrück.{{rp|219}} Grese was captured by the [[British Army]] on 17 April 1945, together with other SS personnel who did not flee.{{cite book|last=Celinscak|first=Mark|title=Distance from the Belsen Heap: Allied Forces and the Liberation of a Concentration Camp|year=2015|publisher=University of Toronto Press|location=Toronto|isbn=9781442615700}} ==War crimes trial== [[File:The Liberation of Bergen-belsen Concentration Camp 1945- Portraits of Belsen Guards at Celle Awaiting Trial, August 1945 BU9745.jpg|thumb|right|Irma Grese and [[Josef Kramer]] in prison in [[Celle]] in August 1945]] Grese was among the 45 people accused of war crimes at the [[Belsen Trial]]. She was tried over the first period of the trials (17 September – 17 November 1945) and was represented by Major L. Cranfield. The trials were conducted under British [[military law]] in [[Lüneburg]], based on charges derived from the [[Geneva Convention (1929)|Geneva Convention of 1929]] regarding the treatment of prisoners. The accusations against her centered on her ill-treatment and murder of those imprisoned at the camps. Survivors provided detailed testimony of murders, tortures, and other cruelties, especially towards women, in which Grese engaged during her years at Auschwitz and Bergen-Belsen. They testified to acts of sadism, beatings, and arbitrary shootings of prisoners, savaging of prisoners by her trained and allegedly half-starved dogs,{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} and her selecting prisoners for the gas chambers. Grese was reported to have habitually worn heavy boots and carried a whip and a pistol.{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} Witnesses testified that she took pleasure in using physical and psychological methods to torture camp inmates and enjoyed shooting prisoners [[wikt:in cold blood|in cold blood]]. They also claimed that she beat some women to death and flogged others using a plaited whip.{{cite web|url=http://www.nizkor.org/hweb/camps/bergen-belsen/belsen-trial-05.html|title=Excerpts from The Belsen Trial (5/5)|website=Nizkor.org|accessdate=7 June 2011}} Under direct examination, Irma Grese testified about her background,
I was born on 7 October 1923. In 1938 I left the elementary school and worked for six months on agricultural jobs at a farm, after which I worked in a shop in [[Lychen]] for six months. When I was 15 I went to a [[Hohenlychen Sanatorium|hospital in Hohenlychen]], where I stayed for two years. I tried to become a nurse but the Labor Exchange would not allow that and sent me to work in a dairy in [[Fürstenberg/Havel|Fürstenberg]]. In July 1942, I tried again to become a nurse, but the Labour Exchange sent me to Ravensbrück Concentration Camp, although I protested against it. I stayed there until March 1943, when I went to Birkenau Camp in Auschwitz. I remained in Auschwitz until January 1945.
During the trial the press labelled Grese as "the Beautiful Beast" alongside Kommandant Josef Kramer ("the Beast of Belsen"). After a nine-week trial, Grese was sentenced to death by hanging.{{cite|url=https://www.upi.com/Archives/1945/12/14/Belsen-Beast-Irma-Grese-hanged-with-nine-other-horror-camp-aides/9191481832607|publisher=UPI|title=Belsen Beast, Irma Grese hanged with nine other horror camp aides|date=14 December 1945}} Although the charges against some of the other female wardens (a total of 16 were charged) were as serious as those against Grese, she was one of only three female guards to be sentenced to death.{{rp|219}} ==Execution== Grese and two other concentration camp workers, [[Juana Bormann|Johanna Bormann]] and [[Elisabeth Volkenrath]], were convicted along with eight men for crimes committed at Auschwitz and Belsen and [[death sentence|sentenced to death]]. As the verdicts were read, Grese was the only prisoner to remain defiant."Verdicts in the Belsen Trial", ''[[The Times]]'', 17 November 1945, pg. 4. Her subsequent [[appeal]] was rejected. According to Wendy Adele-Marie Sarti, the night before her execution, Grese sang [[Nazi songs]] until the early hours of the morning with Johanna Bormann.{{cite|last1=Sarti|first1=Wendy Adele-Marie|title=Women and Nazis|publication-place=Bethesda|publisher=Academica Press|date=2012|isbn=978-1936320127}} On Thursday, 13 December 1945, in {{ill|Hamelin prison|de|Gefängnis Hameln}}, Grese was led to the [[gallows]]. The women were executed singly by [[Hanging#Long drop|long-drop hanging]] and then the men in pairs.The Times; ''Belsen Gang Hanged''; 15 December 1945. Regimental Sergeant Major Richard Anthony O'Neill assisted the British [[executioner]], [[Albert Pierrepoint]]:
We climbed the stairs to the cells where the condemned were waiting. A German officer at the door leading to the corridor flung open the door and we filed past the row of faces and into the execution chamber. The officers stood at attention. Brigadier Paton-Walsh stood with his wristwatch raised. He gave me the signal, and a sigh of released breath was audible in the chamber, I walked into the corridor. 'Irma Grese', I called. The German guards quickly closed all grilles on twelve of the inspection holes and opened one door. Irma Grese stepped out. The cell was far too small for me to go inside, and I had to pinion her in the corridor. 'Follow me,' I said in English, and O'Neil [sic] repeated the order in German. At 9.34 a.m. she walked into the execution chamber, gazed for a moment at the officials standing round it, then walked on to the centre of the trap, where I had made a chalk mark. She stood on this mark very firmly, and as I placed the white cap over her head she said in her languid voice, 'Schnell'. [English translation: 'Quickly'].{{cite news|accessdate=26 September 2012|title=Nazi She-Devils|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/nazi-she-devils-566055|journal=Mirror|date=21 November 2005}} The drop crashed down, and the doctor followed me into the pit and pronounced her dead. After twenty minutes the body was taken down and placed in a coffin ready for burial.{{cite book|title=Executioner|last=Pierrepoint|first=Albert|authorlink=Albert Pierrepoint|year=1974|publisher=Harrap|isbn=978-0-245-52070-9}}
==Dramatizations== Grese has been portrayed as a minor character in two films: ''[[Pierrepoint (film)|Pierrepoint]]'' (2005), which portrays her execution following the Belsen war crimes trial; and ''[[Out of the Ashes (2003 film)|Out of the Ashes]]'' (2003). Both films feature additional female guards in much smaller roles. Grese was briefly portrayed in a nonspeaking reenactment in ''[[Auschwitz: The Nazis and the 'Final Solution']]'' (2005). ==See also== * [[Therese Brandl]] * [[Ilse Koch]] * [[Maria Mandel]] * [[Female guards in Nazi concentration camps]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Irma Grese}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140504231847/http://www.ess.uwe.ac.uk/WCC/belsen5.htm The Belsen Trial], ''Law-Reports of Trials of War Criminals, The United Nations War Crimes Commission, Volume II, London, HMSO, 1947''; {{Infobox person | name = J. Christian Adams | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = John Christian Adams | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1968}} | birth_place = [[Hempfield Township, Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = American | other_names = | occupation = Attorney | education = [[Hempfield Area High School]] | alma_mater = [[West Virginia University]]
[[University of South Carolina School of Law]] }} '''John Christian Adams''' (born 1968){{cite web|title=John Christian Adams|url=http://www.avvo.com/attorneys/john-adams-1822668.html|publisher=Avvo|accessdate=July 7, 2012}}{{cite news|last=Markon|first=Jerry|last2=Thompson|first2=Krissah|title=Dispute over New Black Panthers case causes deep divisions|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/10/22/AR2010102203982_pf.html|accessdate=July 7, 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=October 23, 2010|quote=Adams, 42, was assigned as the lead lawyer.}} is an American attorney and conservative activist{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jul/11/trump-election-integrity-commission-j-christian-adams|title=Controversial rightwing activist to join Trump's election integrity commission|last=Jacobs|first=Ben|date=2017-07-11|work=The Guardian|access-date=2017-11-25|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}} formerly employed by the [[United States Department of Justice]] from 2005 to 2010. After leaving his position in 2010, Adams accused the department of [[racial bias]] in its handling of a [[New Black Panther Party voter intimidation case|voter intimidation case]] against members of the [[New Black Panther Party]]; an internal review by the DOJ Inspector General concluded that opposition to race neutral enforcement of voting laws was widespread in the DOJ Voting Section though particular decisions about the New Black Panther case were defensible.https://oig.justice.gov/reports/2013/s1303.pdf Since leaving the DOJ, Adams has become notable for making claims substantiated by original government records about the extent of [[voter fraud in the United States]]. His organization has published a report detailing extensive non-citizen registration and voting in multiple states. In Virginia, his organization found over 5,500 registrations that were cancelled because of citizenship defects.https://pjmedia.com/jchristianadams/2016/10/03/yes-virginia-aliens-are-registered-and-voting-and-in-pennsylvania-by-the-thousands/ The report republished extensive government records of non-citizen cancellation actions, including full names and detailed information on the registration forms.https://publicinterestlegal.org/files/Alien-Invasion-II-FINAL.pdf Adams is affiliated with an organization that found extensive non-citizen voting in New Jersey, including one alien who was illegally registered three times simultaneously.https://publicinterestlegal.org/blog/garden-state-gotcha-how-opponents-of-citizenship-verification-for-voting-are-putting-new-jerseys-noncitizens-at-risk-of-deportation/ The organization published original voter registration and election records detailing the government records that substantiate the claim of alien registration and voting.https://publicinterestlegal.org/blog/report-noncitizens-discovered-new-jersey-voter-registration-system/ ==Career== Adams grew up in [[Hempfield Township, Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania|Hempfield Township]] in [[Westmoreland County, Pennsylvania]] and graduated from [[Hempfield Area High School]].{{cite news|last=Gazarik|first=Richard|title=Lawyer bashes Obama officials over Philadelphia voter-intimidation case|url=http://triblive.com/x/pittsburghtrib/news/s_688661.html|accessdate=July 7, 2012|newspaper=Pittsburgh Tribune-Review|date=July 2, 2010}} Adams received his [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in [[English language|English]] from [[West Virginia University]], then his [[juris doctor]] from the [[University of South Carolina School of Law]] in 1993, and was admitted to the [[South Carolina Bar]] in 1994.{{cite web|title=The Justice Department and the New Black Panthers Voting Rights Controversy|url=http://www.fed-soc.org/events/detail/the-justice-department-and-the-new-black-panthers-voting-rights-controversy|publisher=Federalist Society|accessdate=July 7, 2012}}{{cite web|title=John Christian Adams search|url=http://www.scbar.org/MemberResources/MemberDirectory.aspx|publisher=South Carolina Bar|accessdate=July 7, 2012}} From 1993 to 1997, Adams served as counsel for [[Jim Miles (politician)|Jim Miles]], the [[Secretary of State of South Carolina]].{{cite news|last=Brundrett|first=Rick|title=Supreme Court not off the hook|url=http://www.thestate.com/local/story/245780.html|newspaper=The State|place=[[Columbia, South Carolina]]|date=December 2, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071204044642/http://www.thestate.com/local/story/245780.html|archivedate=December 4, 2007}} In 1999, the [[Virginia State Bar]] admitted Adams. Adams is an Eagle Scout.{{cite web|title=Obama’s Choice: 100th Anniversary of the Boy Scouts, or Joy Behar?|url=http://pjmedia.com/blog/obamas-choice-100th-anniversary-of-the-boy-scouts-or-joy-behar/?singlepage=true|publisher=PJ Media.|accessdate=February 7, 2014}} ''[[The Washington Times]]'' noted in February 2001 that Adams filed a formal ethics complaint with the [[Florida Bar]] against [[Hugh Edwin Rodham|Hugh Rodham]], brother of then-[[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Hillary Clinton]], that accused Rodham of violating bar regulations by representing people considered for [[presidential pardon]] from former president [[Bill Clinton]], husband of Hillary Rodham Clinton.{{cite web|last=McCaslin|first=John|title=Inside the beltway|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2001/feb/26/20010226-021251-9747r/?page=all|work=The Washington Times|date=February 26, 2001|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010303075302/http://www.washtimes.com/national/inbeltway-200122621315.htm|archivedate=March 3, 2001}} Citing [[United States Department of Justice]] confidentiality rules, the Florida Bar ruled that Hugh Rodham did not violate any rules.{{cite news|last=McCaslin|first=John|title=Inside the beltway|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2001/jul/26/20010726-024433-6310r/?page=all|newspaper=The Washington Times|date=July 26, 2001|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010730040428/http://www.washtimes.com/national/20010726-13951230.htm|archivedate=July 30, 2001}} Adams responded to the Bar by emphasizing that his complaint accused Rodham of illegally taking a [[contingent fee]] to represent the two clients appealing for a pardon.{{cite news|last=McCaslin|first=John|title=Inside the beltway|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2001/jul/30/20010730-024520-1475r/?page=all|newspaper=The Washington Times|date=July 30, 2001}} The ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' reported in 2003 that the [[Transportation Security Administration]] falsely placed Adams in a [[No Fly List]] along with other people with names like "J. Adams".{{cite news|last=Gathright |first=Alan |title=No-fly list ensnares innocent travelers |url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/No-fly-list-ensnares-innocent-travelers-2610926.php |newspaper=San Francisco Chronicle |date=June 8, 2003 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030620164636/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2003%2F06%2F08%2FMN253740.DTL |archivedate=June 20, 2003 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In December 2007, [[Columbia, South Carolina]] newspaper ''[[The State (newspaper)|The State]]'' reported that Adams called on increased oversight of the [[South Carolina Supreme Court]] in response to a controversy over the court reversing the grades of 20 who failed the bar exam. ===Justice Department Civil Rights Division=== {{see also|New Black Panther Party voter intimidation case}} The [[United States Department of Justice]] Civil Rights Division under the [[George W. Bush's second term as President of the United States|George W. Bush administration]] hired Adams in 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.mainjustice.com/2009/12/27/voting-section-chief-out-amid-controversy/|title=Voting Section Chief Out Amid Controversy – Main Justice|last=Reilly|first=Ryan J.|date=|publisher=Mainjustice.com|accessdate=2010-07-06}} In 2008, Adams was one of three federal attorneys probing [[Lake Park, Florida]] for possible bias against African-Americans being elected to town commission.{{cite news|last=Dubocq|first=Tom|title=Feds probe possible racial bias in Lake Park voting|url=http://www.palmbeachpost.com/localnews/content/local_news/epaper/2008/07/19/m1a_justice_0720.html|newspaper=Palm Beach Post|date=July 20, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080904223708/http://www.palmbeachpost.com/localnews/content/local_news/epaper/2008/07/19/m1a_justice_0720.html|archivedate=September 4, 2008}} In December 2009, Adams's supervisor and Civil Rights Division attorney [[Christopher Coates]] stepped down as chief of the voting division in December 2009 amid controversy over his objections to the dropping of the [[New Black Panther Party voter intimidation case]]. Coates' testimony before the [[United States Civil Rights Commission]] supported Adams' allegations,{{cite web|author=Foster, Daniel|title=Coates Testifies at Civil Rights Commission|url=http://www.nationalreview.com/corner/247747/coates-testifies-civil-rights-commission-daniel-foster|work=The Corner|publisher=National Review Online|date=September 24, 2010|accessdate=July 7, 2012}} and the Commission's report that found "a cover-up of a possible racial double standard in law enforcement in the Civil Rights Division of the U.S. Department of Justice," and, detailing "a year of DOJ’s intransigence and baseless refusals to comply with our subpoenas," that "the Department of Justice is unquestionably hostile to any serious investigation of these allegations."{{citation|title=Race Neutral Enforcement of the Law? The U.S. Department of Justice and the New Black Panther Party Litigation: An Interim Report|url=http://www.usccr.gov/NBPH/USCCR_NBPP_report.pdf|publisher=US Commission of Civil Rights|date=December 3, 2010}} In May 2010, Adams resigned from the Justice Department.{{cite web|last=Reilly|first=Ryan J.|title=DOJ lawyer who brought Black Panthers case resigns|url=http://www.mainjustice.com/2010/05/18/doj-lawyer-who-brought-black-panthers-case-resigns/|work=Main Justice|accessdate=July 7, 2012|date=May 18, 2010}} A later internal review by the Department of justice concluded that the dismissal of some charges in the Black Panthers intimidation case was "based on a good-faith assessment of the law and facts of the case" and found "no evidence that partisan politics was a motivating factor in reaching the decision."{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/vote-fraud-crusader-j-christian-adams-sparks-outrage-n796026|title=Vote fraud crusader J. Christian Adams sparks outrage|work=NBC News|access-date=2017-11-25|language=en}} ===Post-Justice Department career=== After leaving the Justice Department, Adams became a contributor to [[Pajamas Media]]. He has been a guest commentator for [[Fox News]], Rush Limbaugh's [http://dailyrushbo.com DailyRushbo.com], [[the Heritage Foundation]], [[Newsmax TV]] and other conservative media. On June 28, 2010, ''[[The Washington Times]]'' published a guest commentary by Adams in which Adams accused the Justice Department of racial bias by dropping the New Black Panthers case.{{cite web|author=Adams, J. Christian|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2010/jun/25/inside-the-black-panther-case-anger-ignorance-and-/?page=all |title=Inside the Black Panther case |publisher=Washington Times |date=June 28, 2010|page=B1}} Subsequently, Adams accused Assistant Attorney General [[Thomas Perez]] of [[perjury|lying under oath]] in investigative hearings before the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights. On July 6, 2010, Adams testified before the Commission on Civil Rights that the Justice Department's decision was driven by racial bias against white Americans.{{cite news|last=Savage|first=Charlie|title=Racial Motive Alleged in a Justice Dept. Decision|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/07/us/07rights.html|accessdate=July 7, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=July 7, 2010}} The Justice Department Inspector General also concluded that a pervasive hostility toward race neutral enforcement of voting laws existed in the DOJ Voting Section.https://oig.justice.gov/reports/2013/s1303.pdf During the [[Virginia Republican primary, 2012|2012 Republican presidential primaries in Virginia]], Adams represented candidate [[Michele Bachmann]] in a multi-candidate lawsuit to add Bachmann and others to the primary ballot in Virginia.{{cite web|last=Higgins|first=Tim|last2=Millard|first2=Mike|title=Virginia’s Cuccinelli Opposes Changes to March Primary Rules|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-01-06/virginia-s-cuccinelli-opposes-changes-to-march-primary-rules.html|publisher=Bloomberg News|accessdate=July 8, 2012|date=January 6, 2012}} Bachmann and the other candidates lost the lawsuit.{{cite news|last=Kumar|first=Anita|title=Perry, Gingrich lose lawsuit to get on Virginia primary ballot|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/dc-politics/perry-gingrich-lose-lawsuit-to-get-on-virginia-primary-ballot/2012/01/13/gIQANoIExP_story.html|accessdate=July 8, 2012|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=January 13, 2012}} ==== Claims about voter fraud ==== Adams advocates for stricter voter ID laws, and has without evidence asserted that there is an "alien invasion" at the voting booth. According to ''NBC News'', "he's spent years suing counties to force them to purge their rolls and he's published personal information online about thousands of registered voters he believes could have committed fraud." Adams has described those who say there is no way to improve the integrity of the electoral system without cancelling the registrations of legitimate voters as "flat-earthers". He has called those who deny the existence of voter fraud as "voter fraud deniers." In 2017, Adams was chosen by President Donald Trump to be a member of his election integrity commission. Adams opposes automatic voter registration, saying that voter registration should require "forethought and initiative, something lacking in large segments of the Democrat base." Adams is affiliated with an organization that found extensive non-citizen voting in New Jersey, including one alien who was illegally registered three times simultaneously.https://publicinterestlegal.org/blog/garden-state-gotcha-how-opponents-of-citizenship-verification-for-voting-are-putting-new-jerseys-noncitizens-at-risk-of-deportation/ The organization published original voter registration and election records detailing the government records that substantiate the claim of alien registration and voting.https://publicinterestlegal.org/blog/report-noncitizens-discovered-new-jersey-voter-registration-system/ ==Bibliography== * {{citation|author=Adams, J. Christian|title=Injustice: Exposing the Racial Agenda of the Obama Justice Department|year=2011|place=[[Washington, D.C.]]|publisher=[[Regnery Publishing]]|isbn=1596982772}} ==See also== *[[Christopher Coates]] *[[New Black Panther Party voter intimidation case]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.electionlawcenter.com Election Law Center, a blog] * [http://pajamasmedia.com/tatler/author/christianadams/ Pajamas Media Contributor Page] {{DEFAULTSORT:Adams, J. Christian}} [[Category:1968 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American whistleblowers]] [[Category:George W. page.title: Kidnapping of children by Nazi Germany

revision.text:
{{Infobox |title=Kidnapping of children by Nazi Germany |image=[[File:Lebensborn document 1.jpg|220px]] |caption=Letter from [[Lebensborn]] office to ''[[Reichsdeutsche]]'' family of Herr Müller in Germany informing that two perfect boys have been found for them to choose one they like. The boys' names have already been Germanized, 18 December 1943 |headerstyle = background:lavender; |datastyle = text-align:left; |header1 = Foreign children abducted |data2 = * 400,000 throughout Europe <ref name=Sereny/> ** 200,000 from occupied Poland <ref name=Berghahn/> ** 28,000 from territory of today's Belarus <ref name=Knoll/> ** 20,000 from the Soviet Union <ref name=Moses260/> ** 10,000 from Western and South Eastern Europe <ref name=Moses260/> Dead in transit, estimated at tens of thousands, and underage inmates used as source of labour supply, not listed }} '''Kidnapping of foreign children by Nazi Germany''' ({{lang-pl|Rabunek dzieci}}), part of the [[Generalplan Ost]] (GPO), involved taking children regarded as "Aryan-looking" from the rest of Europe and moving them to [[Nazi Germany]] for the purpose of [[Germanisation|Germanization]], or indoctrination into becoming culturally German.
At more than 200,000 victims, occupied Poland had the largest proportion of children taken.<ref name=Berghahn>Volker R. Berghahn, "Germans and Poles 1871–1945", in ''Germany and Eastern Europe: Cultural Identities and Cultural Differences''. New York and Amsterdam: Rodopi, 1999.</ref><ref name=Moses247>{{cite book|author=A. Dirk Moses|title=Genocide and Settler Society: Frontier Violence and Stolen Indigenous Children in Australian History|url=https://books.google.com/?id=5zHAGNPTkqIC&pg=PA260&dq=Germanization+%22Polish+children |publisher=New York and Oxford: Berghahn Books, 2004|page =247| accessdate= 2008-09-16 | isbn=978-1-57181-410-4|year=2004}} Limited preview. [[Google Books]].</ref> An estimated 400,000 children were abducted throughout Europe.<ref name=Sereny>[[Gitta Sereny]], [https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Holocaust/children.html "Stolen Children"], rpt. in ''[[Jewish Virtual Library]]'' ([[American-Israeli Cooperative Enterprise]]). Accessed September 15, 2008. (Reprinted by permission of the author from ''Talk'' [November 1999].)</ref>
The aim of the project was to acquire and "[[Germanisation#Under the Third Reich|Germanize]]" children with purportedly [[Aryan race|Aryan]]-[[Nordic race|Nordic]] traits, who were considered by Nazi officials to be descendants of German settlers that had emigrated to Poland. Those labeled "racially valuable" were forcibly Germanized in centers and then sent to German families and SS Home Schools.<ref name=Moses255>{{cite book|author=A. Dirk Moses|title=Genocide and Settler Society: Frontier Violence and Stolen Indigenous Children in Australian History |url=https://books.google.com/?id=5zHAGNPTkqIC&pg=PA260&dq=Germanization+%22Polish+children| location =New York and Oxford | publisher = Berghahn Books | year = 2004|page =255|accessdate=2008-09-16 | isbn=978-1-57181-410-4}}</ref> In the case of older children used as [[forced labor]] in Germany those determined to be racially un-"German" were sent to [[extermination camp]]s and [[concentration camp]]s, where they were either to be murdered or forced to serve as living test subjects in [[Nazi human experimentation|German medical experiments]] and thus often tortured or killed in the process.<ref name=Lukas/>
==Historical contexts== {{See also|Occupation of Poland (1939–1945)|Nazi crimes against ethnic Poles}} In a well-known speech to his military commanders at Obersalzberg on 22 August 1939, Adolf Hitler condoned the killing without pity or mercy of all men, women, and children of Polish race or language.<ref name =Milton>{{cite web | author = Sybil Milton|url=http://motlc.wiesenthal.com/site/pp.asp?c=gvKVLcMVIuG&b=395115|title=Non-Jewish Children in the Camps|work = Multimedia Learning Center Online (Annual 5, Chapter 2)| year = 1997 |publisher= The [[Simon Wiesenthal Center]]|accessdate= 2008-09-25}}</ref>
On 7 November 1939, Hitler decreed that [[Heinrich Himmler]], whose German title at that time was Reichskomissar für die Festigung deutschen Volkstums, would be responsible for policy regarding the population of occupied territories. The plan to kidnap Polish children most likely was created in a document titled ''Rassenpolitisches Amt der NSDAP''.<ref name=Hrabar28/>
On 25 November 1939, Himmler was sent a 40-page document titled (in English translation) "The issue of the treatment of population in former Polish territories from a racial-political view."<ref name=Hrabar28>{{cite book|author=Roman Zbigniew Hrabar|title=Hitlerowski rabunek dzieci polskich: Uprowadzanie i germanizowanie dzieci polskich w latach 1939-1945 | publisher=Śląski Instytut Naukowy w Katowicach, Katowice: Wydawnictwo Śląsk | year = 1960|page =28 | language = Polish}}</ref> The last chapter of the document concerns "racially valuable" Polish children and plans to forcefully acquire them for German plans and purposes:
{{quote|we should exclude from deportations racially valuable children and raise them in old Reich in proper educational facilities or in German family care. The children must not be older than eight or ten years, because only till this age we can truly change their national identification, that is "final Germanization". A condition for this is complete separation from any Polish relatives. Children will be given German names, their ancestry will be led by special office.<ref name=Hrabar28/>}}
On 15 May 1940, in a document titled (in German) ''Einige Gedanken ueber die Behandlung der Fremdenvoelker im Osten'' ("A Few Thoughts about the Treatment of Racial Aliens in the East"), and in another "top-secret memorandum with limited distribution, dated 25 May 1940", titled (in English translation) "The Treatment of Racial Aliens in the East", Himmler defined special directives for the kidnapping of Polish children.<ref name=Milton/><ref name = Hrabar29>{{cite book|author=Roman Zbigniew Hrabar|title = Hitlerowski rabunek dzieci polskich: Uprowadzanie i germanizowanie dzieci polskich w latach 1939-1945 |publisher=Śląski Instytut Naukowy w Katowicach, Katowice: Wydawnictwo Śląsk | year = 1960 |page = 29}}</ref> Himmler "also outlined the administration of incorporated Poland and the [[General Government]], where Poles were to be assigned to compulsory labor, and racially selected children were to be abducted and Germanized."<ref name=Milton/>
Among Himmler's core points:<ref name=Hrabar28/> *In the territory of Poland, only four [[Primary school|grade schools]] would remain, in which education would be strictly limited. Children would be taught to count only to 500, to write their own name, and that God commanded Poles to serve Germans. Writing was determined to be unnecessary for the Polish population. *Parents who desired better education for their children would have to apply to the [[Schutzstaffel|SS]] and police for a special permit. The permit would be awarded to children deemed "racially valuable". Those children would be taken to Germany to be Germanised. Even then, the fate of each child would be determined by the loyalty and obedience to the German state of his or her parents. A child determined to be "of little racial value" would not receive any further education. *Annual selection would be made every year among children from six to ten years of age according to German racial standards. Children deemed adequately German would be taken to Germany, given new names and further Germanised.<ref name = Hrabar28/> The aim of the plan was to destroy "[[Poles|Polish]]" as an ethnic group, and leave within Poland a considerable slave population to be used up over the next 10 years. Within 15 to 20 years, Poles would be completely eradicated.<ref name="Germany">{{Cite journal | title = Germany and Eastern Europe: Cultural Identities and Cultural Differences | first1 = Keith | last1 = Bullivant | first2 = Geoffrey J | last2 = Giles | first3 = Walter | last3 = Pape | publisher = Rodopi | year = 1999 | page = 32}}</ref>
On 20 June 1940, Hitler approved Himmler's directives, ordering copies to be sent to chief organs of the SS, to [[Gauleiter]]s in German-occupied territories in Central Europe, and to the governor of General Government, and commanding that the operation of kidnapping Polish children in order to seek Aryan descendants for Germanisation be a priority in those territories. Between 1940 and 1945, according to official Polish estimates, approximately 200,000 Polish children were abducted by the Nazis.<ref>''Nowa Encyklopedia Powszechna PWN'' (Warsaw: Wydawnictwo Naukowe PWN, 2004), 2: 613. {{ISBN|83-01-14181-6}}.</ref><ref name=Madajczyk>{{cite book|author = Czesław Madajczyk|title=Generalna Gubernia w planach hitlerowskich. Studia|publisher=Warsaw: Państwowe Wydawnictwo Naukowe | year = 1961|page = 49 | language = Polish}}</ref><ref name =Hrabar93>{{cite book|author=Roman Z. Hrabar|title=Hitlerowski rabunek dzieci polskich: Uprowadzanie i germanizowanie dzieci polskich w latach 1939-1945 |publisher=Śląski Instytut Naukowy w Katowicach, Katowice: Wydawnictwo Śląsk | year = 1960|page =93 | language = Polish}}</ref>
===Outside Poland=== Large numbers of children were also abducted from places other than Poland: about 20,000 children were taken from the Soviet Union and about 10,000 children were taken from Western and South Eastern Europe.<ref name=Moses260>{{cite book|author=A. Dirk Moses|title=Genocide and Settler Society: Frontier Violence and Stolen Indigenous Children in Australian History |url=https://books.google.com/?id=5zHAGNPTkqIC&pg=PA260&dq=Germanization+%22Polish+children|publisher= Berghahn Books | location = New York and Oxford| year = 2004 | page = 260 | isbn=978-1-57181-410-4}} Limited preview. [[Google Books]].<!--This page does not appear to be part of the "Limited preview".--></ref>
Himmler mused on initiating similar projects in [[German occupation of France during World War II|German-occupied France]].<ref name="table">Hitler, Adolf; [[Gerhard Weinberg|Weinberg, Gerhard L.]] (2007). ''Hitler's table talk, 1941-1944: his private conversations'', p. 303. Enigma Books.</ref> [[Hitler's Table Talk]] records him expressing his belief that "the [[France|French]] problem" would be best solved by yearly extractions of a number of racially healthy children, chosen from "France's Germanic population". He preferred they be placed in German [[boarding school]]s, in order to separate them from their "incidental" French nationality, and to make them aware of their "Germanic blood". Hitler responded that the "religious [[petit-bourgeois]] tendencies of the French people" would make it almost impossible to "salvage the Germanic elements from the claws of the [[ruling class]] of that country".<ref name="table"/> [[Martin Bormann]] believed it to be an ingenious policy, [[Note (typography)|noting]] it in the document record as a [sic] "sinister theory!".<ref name="table"/>
==Conditions of transfer== [[File:Kidnapping of Polish children by Nazi-German occupants (Zamojszczyzna).jpg|thumb|250px|Kidnapping of Polish children during the Nazi-German resettlement operation in [[Zamość]] county.]] {{See also|Expulsion of Poles by Nazi Germany|Ethnic cleansing of Zamojszczyzna by Nazi Germany}}
A large percentage of children were kidnapped during expulsions of Poles by Nazi Germany as part of [[Lebensraum]] policy. In the [[Zamość County]] alone, some 30,000 children were apprehended.<ref name="IPN2003">{{cite journal |title=Polacy wypędzeni |publisher=Biuletyn Instytutu Pamięci Narodowej, Pamięć.pl |volume=5 |issue=40 |date=May 2004 |pages=18–22 (16–20/24 in PDF) |work=Dzieci Zamojszczyzny |author=Julian Grudzień |quote=... to co, się działo na Zamojszczyźnie, szczególnie w pierwszym rzucie wysiedleń, począwszy od listopada 1942 r. i zimą, do lutego 1943 r., to była sprawa wręcz nie do opowiedzenia; mróz sięgał trzydziestu stopni i poniżej. I w takich warunkach rozpoczęły się transporty kolejowe z obozu zamojskiego (od 10 listopada 1942 r.) w okolice Siedlec. |url=http://pamiec.pl/download/49/29228/biuletyn540.pdf}}</ref> Of the 200,000 Polish children deported by the Germans before the war's end, only 15-20 percent were recovered.<ref name=Lukas/> Over 10,000 children died in camps at [[Zwierzyniec]], [[Zamość]], [[Auschwitz]], [[Majdanek]] or during transport in [[Stock car (rail)|cattle wagons]] used normally to move [[livestock]]. Thousands of them were sent by railway to [[Garwolin]], [[Mrozów]], [[Sobolew, Masovian Voivodeship|Sobolew]], [[Łosice]], [[Chełm]] and other cities. As one witness reported: "I saw children being taken from their mothers, some were even torn from the breast. It was a terrible sight: the agony of the mothers and fathers, the beating by the Germans, and the crying of the children."<ref name=Lukas>{{Cite book | first = Richard C | last = Lukas | title = Germanization | url = http://www.projectinposterum.org/docs/lucas3.htm | work = Did the Children Cry? Hitler's War against Jewish and Polish Children, 1939–1945 | location = New York | publisher = Hippocrene Books | year = 2001 | accessdate = September 15, 2008 | chapter = 2, 3}}</ref>
The conditions of transfer were very harsh, as the children did not receive food or water for many days.<ref name="lukas22">Richard C. Lukas, ''Forgotten Holocaust'' p. 22, {{ISBN|0-7818-0528-7}}.</ref> Many children died as a result of suffocation in the summer and cold in the winter.<ref name="lukas22"/> Polish railway workers, often risking their lives, tried to feed the imprisoned children or to give them warm clothes. Sometimes the German guards could be bribed with jewelry or gold to allow the supplies to go through, and in other cases they sold some of the children to Poles.<ref name="lukas22"/> In [[Bydgoszcz]] and [[Gdynia]], Poles bought children for 40 Reichsmarks. In some places the German price for a Polish child was 25 zlotys.<ref name=Lukas/>
The children were kidnapped by force, often after their parents had been murdered in concentration camps or shot as "partisans", including a handful of the children of [[Lidice]].<ref>[[Lynn H. Nicholas]], ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 253-4 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref> These children would not be permitted to remain even with other living relatives.<ref>Richard C. Lukas, ''Forgotten Holocaust'' p. 27, {{ISBN|0-7818-0528-7}}.</ref> Some were purportedly from German soldiers and foreign mothers, and others were declared "German orphans" who had been raised by non-German families.<ref name=Moses248>{{cite book|author=A. Dirk Moses|title=Genocide and Settler Society: Frontier Violence and Stolen Indigenous Children in Australian History|url = https://books.google.com/?id=5zHAGNPTkqIC&pg=PA260&dq=Germanization+%22Polish+children| location =New York and Oxford | publisher = Berghahn Books | year = 2004|page =248|accessdate= 2008-09-16 | isbn=978-1-57181-410-4}} Limited preview. [[Google Books]].</ref> Indeed, orphanages and children's homes, along with children living with [[foster parent]]s, were among the first groups targeted, in the belief that Poles deliberately and systemically Polonized ethnically German children.<ref>Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 244-5 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref> German foster parents were later told that children had received false Polish birth certificates to rob them of their German heritage.<ref name=Sereny/>
Later the children were sent to special centers and institutions or to, as Germans called them, "children education camps" (''Kindererziehungslager''), which, in reality, were selection camps where their "racial values" were tested, their original metrics of birth destroyed, and their Polish names changed to German names, as part of [[Germanisation]]. Those children who were classified as "of little value" were sent to [[Auschwitz-Birkenau|Auschwitz]] or to [[Treblinka]].<ref name=Lukas/>
==Selection== [[File:Litzmannstadt Ghetto plan.svg|thumb|250px|Kinder-KZ inside [[Litzmannstadt Ghetto]] map signed with number 15; where Polish children were selected.]] [[File:Polish children in Nazi-German labor camp in Dzierżązna.jpg|thumb|250px|Polish children in Nazi-German labor camp in Dzierżązna near [[Zgierz]].]] {{see also|Kinder KZ|Untermensch}}
The children were placed in special temporary camps of the health department, or [[Lebensborn]] e.V., called in German ''Kindererziehungslager'' ("children's education camps"). Afterwards they went through special "quality selection" or "racial selection" — a detailed racial examination, combined with psychological tests and medical exams made by experts from [[SS-Rasse- und Siedlungshauptamt|RuSHA]] or doctors from [[Gesundheitsamt]] (health department). A child's "racial value" would determine to which of 11 racial types it was assigned, including 62 points assessing body proportions, eye color, hair color, and the shape of the skull.
During this testing process, children were divided into three groups (in English translation): #"desired population growth" ({{lang|de|erwünschter Bevölkerungszuwachs}}); #"acceptable population growth" ({{lang|de|tragbarer Bevölkerungszuwachs}}); and #"undesired population growth" ({{lang|de|unerwünschter Bevölkerungszuwachs}}).<ref name=Hrabar43>{{cite book|author=Roman Z. Hrabar|title=Hitlerowski rabunek dzieci polskich: Uprowadzanie i germanizowanie dzieci polskich w latach 1939-1945|publisher=Śląski Instytut Naukowy w Katowicach, Katowice: Wydawnictwo Śląsk, 1960|page = 43}}</ref> The failures that could result in a child, otherwise fitting all racial criteria, into the second group included such traits as "round-headed" referring to [[Cephalic index|the skull shape]].<ref name="Lynn H. Nicholas p 250">Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 250 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref> Children could be declared the third group for [[tuberculosis]], "degenerate" skull shape, or for "Gypsy characteristics".<ref name="cruel251">Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 251 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref> A girl who was later identified by a small birthmark would have been rejected had the birthmark been much larger.<ref name=Sereny/>
These racial exams determined the fate of children: whether they would be killed, or sent to concentration camps, or experience other consequences. For example, after forcibly taking a child away from his or her parents, "medical exams" could be performed in secret and in disguise.<ref name=Hrabar44>{{cite book|author=Roman Z. Hrabar|title=Hitlerowski rabunek dzieci polskich: Uprowadzanie i germanizowanie dzieci polskich w latach 1939-1945 |publisher=Śląski Instytut Naukowy w Katowicach, Katowice: Wydawnictwo Śląsk, 1960|page =44}}</ref>
Many Nazis were astounded at the number of Polish children found to exhibit "Nordic" traits, but assumed that all such children were genuinely German children, who had been [[Polonization|Polonized]]; [[Hans Frank]] summoned up such views when he declared, "When we see a blue-eyed child we are surprised that she is speaking Polish."<ref name=Lukas/> Among those children thought to be genuinely German were children whose parents had been executed for resisting Germanization.<ref name=Gumkowkski>{{cite book|url=http://www.dac.neu.edu/holocaust/Hitlers_Plans.htm |title=Hitler's Plans for Eastern Europe |author=Janusz Gumkowski and Kazimierz Leszczyński |location=Warsaw |publisher=Polonia Publishing House |year=1961 |accessdate=2008-09-22 |pages=7–33; 164–78 |work=Poland Under Nazi Occupation |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120527021449/http://www.dac.neu.edu/holocaust/Hitlers_Plans.htm |archivedate=2012-05-27 |df= }}</ref>
==German documentation== Once selected, the children between six and twelve were sent to special homes. Their names were altered to similar-sounding German ones.<ref>Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p. 249 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref> They were compelled to learn German and beaten if they persisted in speaking Polish.<ref name=Eddy>{{cite news|author=Melissa Eddy|title=Stolen: The Story of a Polish Child 'Germanized' by the Nazis|work=StarNewsOnline (Wilmington, North Carolina)|publisher=[[Associated Press]]|url=http://www.starnewsonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20070508/NEWS/705080331/-1/State|date= 2007-05-08|accessdate=2008-09-16|quote=If they met racial guidelines, they were taken; one girl got back home.}}</ref> They were informed their parents were dead even if they were not.<ref name=Gumkowkski/> Children who would not learn German or remembered their Polish origin were sent back to youth camps in Poland.<ref name="Lynn H. Nicholas p 250"/> In some cases, the efforts were so successful that the children lived and died believing themselves to be Germans.<ref name=Lukas/> Very young children, between two and six, were sent to [[Lebensborn]] homes, which had originally been instituted to provide shelter for unwed mothers and illegitimate children deemed racially valuable. There, they would be observed for a period.<ref name="Sereny"/>
In either case, if they were not disqualified at the respective institution, they were placed for adoption. The Nazis would devise German names and new birth certificates to hide their pasts. In the process, they were referred to as "[[Polonization|Polonized]] German children" or "Children of German descent" or even "German orphans."<ref name=Lukas/> Orders forbade making the term "Germanizable Polish children" known to the public.<ref name=Sereny/> This was to prevent their being viewed as Poles by the people they met, and so stigmatized. Some parents were informed that the children's birth certificates had been falsified, to show them as Poles and rob them of their German heritage.<ref name=Sereny/> The authorities were reluctant to let the children be officially adopted, as the proceedings might reveal their Polish origin. Indeed, some children were maltreated when their adoptive parents learned that they were Polish.<ref name=Gumkowkski/>
Adoption was also problematic because surveillance or more information might reveal problems with the child.<ref name="cruel251"/> When it was learned that Rosalie K's mother was epileptic, for instance, it was immediately concluded, despite the wishes of her German foster parents, that Germanization, education and adoption were therefore not justifiable.<ref>Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 251-2 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref>
When adoptive parents demanded adoption certificates, such records were forged for them.<ref name="cruel251"/>
==Murder of Zamość children in Auschwitz== [[File:Czeslawa-Kwoka2.jpg|thumb|[[Czesława Kwoka]], one of many Polish children murdered at Auschwitz by the Nazis]]
At [[Auschwitz concentration camp]] 200 to 300 Polish children from the [[Zamość]] area were murdered by the Nazis by [[phenol]] injections. The child was placed on a stool, occasionally blindfolded with a piece of a towel. The person performing the execution then placed one of his hands on the back of the child's neck and another behind the shoulder blade. As the child's chest was thrust out a long needle was used to inject a toxic dose of phenol into the chest. The children usually died in minutes. A witness described the process as deadly efficient: "As a rule not even a moan would be heard. And they did not wait until the doomed person really died. During his agony, he was taken from both sides under the armpits and thrown into a pile of corpses in another room… And the next victim took his place on the stool."<ref name=Lukas41>{{Cite book | first = Richard C | last = Lukas | title = Germanization | url = http://www.projectinposterum.org/docs/lucas2.htm | work = Did the Children Cry? Hitler's War against Jewish and Polish Children, 1939–1945 | location = New York | publisher = Hippocrene Books | year = 2001 | accessdate = May 1, 2016 | chapter = 4, 1}}</ref>
To trick the soon-to-be murdered children into obedience Germans promised them that they would work at a brickyard. However another group of children, young boys by the age of 8 to 12, managed to warn their fellow child inmates by calling for help when they were being killed by the Nazis: "Mamo! Mamo!" ('Mum! Mum!'), the dying screams of the youngsters, were heard by several inmates and made an indelible haunting impression on them.'"<ref name=Lukas41/>
Some of the children were also murdered in Auschwitz [[gas chamber]]s; others died as a result of the camp conditions.<ref name=Block6>{{cite web|url= http://www.auschwitz.org.pl/new/index.php?language=EN&tryb=stale&id=442|title=Block no. 6: Exhibition: The Life of the Prisoners |publisher=Auschwitz-Birkenau State Museum, Poland|accessdate=2008-09-03|quote=Part of the exhibition in Block 6. In this block, there is a presentation of the conditions under which people became concentration camp prisoners and died as a result of inhumanly hard labor, starvation, disease, and experiments, as well as executions and various types of torture and punishment. There are photographs here of prisoners who died in the camp, documents, and works of art illustrating camp life. Auschwitz I. Exhibition department | author = Photograph by Ryszard Domasik| location = Poland|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071018064545/http://www.auschwitz.org.pl/new/index.php?language=EN&tryb=stale&id=442|archivedate=2007-10-18}}</ref>
==German medical experiments on kidnapped children== Those children who did not pass harsh Nazi exams and criteria and who were therefore selected during the operation, were sent as test subjects for experiments in special centers.<ref name=Uzarczyk>{{cite book|author=Kamila Uzarczyk|title=Podstawy ideologiczne higieny ras|publisher=Toruń: Wydawnictwo Adam Marszałek, 2002|pages=285–89|isbn=83-7322-287-1}}</ref> Children sent there ranged from eight months to 18 years. Two such centres were located in German-occupied Poland. One of them, Medizinische Kinderheilanstalt, was in [[Lubliniec]] in [[Upper Silesia]] – in this centre children were also subject to forced "[[euthanasia]]";<ref name=Uzarczyk/> while the second was located in [[Cieszyn]]. Children were given [[psychoactive]] drugs, chemicals and other substances for medical tests, although it was generally known that the true purpose of those procedures was their mass extermination.<ref name=Uzarczyk/>
Weaker children subject to experiments usually died in a relatively short time from doses of drugs, and those that survived brought great curiosity; all side effects were recorded as well as their behavior. As most died, the documentation was forged to conceal traces of experiments, for example, giving the cause of death as from a lung infection or a weak heart. Based on statistics of deaths in the special camp in [[Lublin]], it was estimated that from the 235 children between ages 10 to 14 who received shots of the [[barbiturate]] [[Phenobarbital|Luminal]], 221 died.<ref name=Uzarczyk/> From August 1942 until November 1944, 94 percent of children who had been subjected to German medical experiments died.{{Citation needed|date=September 2008}}
==Heuaktion== {{main|Heuaktion}} In a plan called "[[Heuaktion]]", described in a "top secret" memorandum submitted to German [[Interior Minister]] [[Heinrich Himmler]] on 10 June 1944, [[Schutzstaffel|SS]]–[[Obergruppenfuehrer]] [[Gottlob Berger]] — Chief of the Political Directing Staff (head of the SS main leadership office in Berlin), a co-author of Himmler's pamphlet ''Der [[Untermensch]]'', and a promoter of the pamphlet ''Mit Schwert und Wiege'' (''With Sword and Cradle'') for the recruitment of non-Germans — proposed that the [[9th Army (Wehrmacht)|German 9th Army]] "evacuate" 40,000–50,000 children between 10 and 14 from the "territory of Army Group 'Center' " to work for the [[Third Reich]].<ref name=Avalon>{{cite book| title = Memorandum: Re: Evacuation of youths from the territory of Army Group "Center" (Heu-Aktion)| url = http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/imt/document/031-ps.htm| work = The Avalon Project: Nazi Conspiracy and Aggression| volume = 2| publisher = [[The Avalon Project]] ([[Yale University]])| date = 1944-06-12| accessdate = 2008-09-24| quote = Translation of Document 031-PS: Chief of the Political Directing Staff, personal referee, Berlin, 12 June 1944: TOP SECRET: Copy No. 1 of 2 copies: The Army Group 'Center' has the intention to apprehend 40–50,000 youths at the ages of 10 to 14 who are in the Army Territories, and to transport them to the Reich. This measure was originally proposed by the 9th Army. These youths cause considerable inconvenience in the Theatre of Operations. To the greater part these youths are without supervision of their parents since men and women in the theatres of operations have been and will be conscripted into labor battalions to be used in the construction of fortifications. Therefore Children's Villages are to be established behind the front, for the younger age groups, and under native supervision. To collect adequate experiences the 9th Army has already established such a Children's Village and has achieved good results also from the political viewpoint. Army Group further emphasizes that these youths must not be allowed! [sic] to fall into the hands of the [[Bolshevik]]s in case of a withdrawal since that would amount to reinforcing the enemy's potential war strength. This measure is to be strongly fortified by propaganda under the slogan: Care of the Reich for White-Ruthenian Children, Protection against Brigandry. The action has already started in the 5 kilometer zone. The Youth Bureau has already had preliminary talks with the Organization Todt and with the Junkers works. It is intended to allot these juveniles primarily to the German trades as apprentices to be used as skilled workers after 2 years' training. This is to be arranged through the Organization Todt which is especially equipped for such a task through its technical and other set-ups. This action is being… greatly welcomed by the German trade since it represents a decisive measure for the alleviation of the shortage of apprentices[.]| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080519221444/http://www.yale.edu/lawweb/avalon/imt/document/031-ps.htm| archivedate = 19 May 2008| df = }}</ref>
Heuaktion was not widely implemented, due in part perhaps to the following arguments against it: "The Minister [Himmler] feared that the action would have most unfavorable political consequences, that it would be regarded as abduction of children, and that the juveniles did not represent a real asset to the enemy's military strength anyhow.... The Minister would like to see the action confined to the 15–17 year olds."<ref name=Avalon/> Between March and October 1944, however, 28,000 children between the ages of 10 and 18 were deported from [[Belarus]] for work in the German arms industry.<ref name=Knoll>{{cite book |author=Harald Knoll |title=Späte Heimkehr Als Kriegsverbrecher verurteilte österreichische Kriegsgefangene in der Sowjetunion 1944 bis 1953 |work=Kriegsgefangene des Zweiten Weltkrieges: Gefangennahme, Lagerleben, Rückkehr : zehn Jahre Ludwig Boltzmann-Institut für Kriegsfolgen-Forschung |editors=[[Günter Bischof]], Stefan Karner, Barbara Stelzl-Marx, Edith Petschnigg |at=p. 177 (pp. 167–183) |url=https://books.google.com/?id=5M4WAQAAIAAJ&q=Wei%C3%9Frussland+28.000 |publisher=Munich and Wien: Oldenbourg Wissenschaftsverlag |year=2005 |isbn=3486578189 |via=[[Google Books]] snippet; no Limited preview available}}</ref><ref name=Richter>{{cite book |author=Timm C. Richter |title="Herrenmensch" und "Bandit" |url = https://books.google.com/?id=U8yALlPjCLYC&pg=PA106&dq=%22Heu+aktion%22 | series = Deutsche Kriegsführung und Besatzungspolitik als Kontext des sowjetischen Partisanenkrieges (1941-44)|publisher=Reihe: Zeitgeschichte — Zeitverständnis | year = 1998|volume=3|page =106|isbn=3-8258-3680-0}} Limited preview. [[Google Books]].</ref>
==Post-war== The extent of the program became clear to Allied forces over the course of months, as they found groups of "Germanized" children and became aware that many more were in the German population.<ref>Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 501-2 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref> Locating these children turned up their stories of forcible instruction in the German language and how the failures were killed.<ref>Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 502 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref> Teams were constituted to search for the children, a particularly important point when dealing with institutions, where a single investigator could only interview a few children before all the rest were coached to provide false information.<ref>Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 505 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref> Many children had to be lured into speaking the truth; as for instance complimenting their German and asking how long they had spoken it, and only when told that a nine-year-old had spoken German for four years, pointing out that they must have spoken before then, whereupon the child could be brought to admit to having spoken Polish.<ref>Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 506 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref> Some children suffered emotional trauma when they were removed from their adoptive German parents, often the only parents they remembered, and returned to their biological parents, when they no longer remembered Polish, only German.<ref name=Sereny/> The older children generally remembered Poland; ones as young as ten had forgotten much, but could often be reminded by such things as Polish nursery rhymes; the youngest had no memories that could be recalled.<ref name=Sereny/>
Allied forces made efforts to repatriate them.<ref name="cruel479"/> However, many children, particularly Polish and Yugoslavian who were among the first taken, declared on being found that they were German.<ref name="cruel479">Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 479 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref> Russian and Ukrainian children, while not gotten to this stage, still had been taught to hate their native countries and did not want to return.<ref name="cruel479"/> While many foster parents voluntarily brought forth well-cared-for children, other children proved to be abused or used for labor, and still others went to great efforts to hide the children.<ref>Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 508-9 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref>
After the war, The United States of America v. [[Ulrich Greifelt]], et al., or the [[RuSHA Trial]], the eighth of the twelve [[Nuremberg Trials]], dealt with the kidnapping of children by the Nazis.<ref>Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 507 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref> Many children testified, although many of their parents were afraid to let them return to Germany.<ref>Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 507-8 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref> From 1947 to 1948, the [[Nuremberg Trials]] ruled that the abductions, exterminations, and Germanization constituted [[genocide]].<ref name=Greifetetal>{{cite web |title= Trial of Ulrich Greifelt and Others, United States Military Tribunal, Nuremberg, 10 October 1947 – 10 March 1948, Part IV|url=http://164.11.131.30/WCC/greifelt4.htm|quote= [T]he crime of genocide… was taken by the prosecution and the Tribunal as a general concept defining the background of the total range of specific offences committed by the accused, which in themselves constitute crimes against humanity and/or war crimes.|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070611031358/http://164.11.131.30/WCC/greifelt4.htm|archivedate=2007-06-11}}</ref>
Only 10 to 15 percent of those abducted returned to their homes.<ref name=Piotrowski>{{cite book|first =Tadeusz | last = Piotrowski|title=Poland's Holocaust: Ethnic Strife, Collaboration with Occupying Forces and Genocide in the Second Republic, 1918–1947|url=https://books.google.com/?id=A4FlatJCro4C&pg=PA22&dq=Germanization+%22Polish+children%22| location =Jefferson, North Carolina | publisher = McFarland & Co | year = 1998|page =22|isbn = 978-0-7864-0371-4 }}</ref> When Allied effort to identify such children ceased, 13,517 inquiries were still open, and it was clear that German authorities would not be returning them.<ref>Lynn H. Nicholas, ''Cruel World: The Children of Europe in the Nazi Web'' p 513 {{ISBN|0-679-77663-X}}</ref>
Today in Germany, it is believed that hundreds of thousands of Germans might be descended from kidnapped Polish children. However it is very unlikely that people are aware of having hidden Polish ancestry, and cases of having any such knowledge are extremely rare.{{Citation needed|reason=Such a bold statement could really do with a source|date=December 2016}}
After the war, a memorial plate was made in [[Lublin]] dedicated to railway workers who tried to save Polish children from German captivity.<ref name= Szubiak>{{cite web|author=Marek J. Szubiak|url=http://roztocze.net/newsroom.php/13293|title=Dzieciństwo zabrała wojna|work=Newsroom|publisher=Roztocze Online (P. Rogalski & R. Moteka)|date=2002-12-10|accessdate=2008-09-24 | language = Polish}}</ref>

Gräfin Beatrix von Kageneck | relatives = | website = }} '''Klemens Wenzel Nepomuk Lothar, Prince von Metternich-Winneburg zu Beilstein''', [[Order of the Golden Fleece|KOGF]] ({{IPA-de|ˈmɛtɐnɪç|lang}}; 15 May 1773 – 11 June 1859){{harvnb|Palmer|1972|pp=5–6, 339}} was an Austrian diplomat who was at the center of European affairs for four decades as the [[Austrian Empire]]'s foreign minister from 1809 and [[List of Ministers-President of Austria|Chancellor]] from 1821 until the liberal [[Revolutions of 1848]] forced his resignation. One of his first assignments was to engineer a [[détente]] with France that included the marriage of [[Napoleon]] to the Austrian archduchess [[Marie Louise, Duchess of Parma|Marie Louise]]. Soon after, he engineered Austria's entry into the [[War of the Sixth Coalition]] on the Allied side, signed the [[Treaty of Fontainebleau (1814)|Treaty of Fontainebleau]] that sent Napoleon into exile and led the Austrian delegation at the [[Congress of Vienna]] that divided post-Napoleonic Europe amongst the major powers. For his service to the Austrian Empire, he was given the title of Prince in October 1813. Under his guidance, the "[[Metternich system]]" of international congresses continued for another decade as Austria aligned itself with Russia and to a lesser extent Prussia. This marked the high point of Austria's diplomatic importance and thereafter Metternich slowly slipped into the periphery of international diplomacy. At home, Metternich held the post of Chancellor of State from 1821 until 1848 under both [[Francis I of Austria|Francis I]] and his son [[Ferdinand I of Austria|Ferdinand I]]. After a brief exile in London, Brighton, and Brussels that lasted until 1851, he returned to the Viennese court, this time to offer only advice to Ferdinand's successor, [[Franz Josef I of Austria|Franz Josef]]. Having outlived his generation of politicians, Metternich died at the age of 86 in 1859. Born in 1773 into the family of a prosperous and well-connected, if relatively minor, [[Rhenish]] nobility,Ryan M. Nadeau, [https://cupola.gettysburg.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://www.google.ca/&httpsredir=1&article=1148&context=ghj "Creating a Statesman: The Early Life of Prince Clemens von Metternich and its Effect on his Political Philosophy"], ''The Gettysburg Historical Journal'', volume 15, 2016, p. 65–66 the son of a diplomat, he was named after his godfather, [[Prince Clemens Wenceslaus of Saxony|Clement-Wenceslas, Archbishop of Trier]]. Metternich received a good education at the universities of [[University of Strasbourg|Strasbourg]] and [[University of Mainz|Mainz]]. He was of help during the coronation of Francis II in 1792 and that of his predecessor, [[Leopold II, Holy Roman Emperor|Leopold II]], in 1790. After a brief trip to England, Metternich was named as the Austrian ambassador to the Netherlands, a short-lived post since the country was brought under French control the next year. He married his first wife, Eleonore von Kaunitz (a descendant of [[Karolina of Legnica-Brieg]]) in 1795, which aided his entry into Viennese society. Despite having numerous affairs, he was devastated by her death in 1825. His second marriage was to Baroness Antoinette Leykam in 1827 and following her death in 1829 married Countess Melanie Zichy-Ferraris in 1831. She predeceased him by five years. Before taking office as Foreign Minister, Metternich held numerous smaller posts, including ambassadorial roles in the [[Kingdom of Saxony]], the [[Kingdom of Prussia]], and Napoleonic France. One of Metternich's sons, [[Richard von Metternich]], was also a successful diplomat and many of Metternich's twelve other acknowledged children predeceased him. A [[Traditionalist conservatism|traditional conservative]], Metternich was keen to maintain the [[Balance of power in international relations|balance of power]], in particular by resisting Russian territorial ambitions in Central Europe and lands belonging to the [[Ottoman Empire]]. He disliked [[liberalism]] and strove to prevent the breakup of the Austrian Empire, for example, by crushing [[nationalism|nationalist]] revolts in Austrian north Italy and the German states. At home, he pursued a similar policy, using [[censorship]] and a wide-ranging spy network to suppress unrest. Metternich has been both praised and heavily criticized for the policies he pursued. His supporters point out that he presided over the "[[Age of Metternich]]", when international diplomacy helped prevent major wars in Europe. His qualities as a diplomat are commended, some noting that his achievements were considerable in light of the weakness of his negotiating position. His decision to oppose Russian expansionism is seen as a good one. His detractors describe him as a boor who stuck to ill-thought-out, conservative principles out of vanity and a sense of infallibility. They argue he could have done much to secure Austria's future, instead his 1817 proposals for administrative reform were largely rejected and his opposition to [[German nationalism]] is blamed for [[Unification of Germany|Germany's unification under Prussia]] and not Austria. Other historians have argued that he had far less power than this view suggests and that his policies were only exercised when they were in accord with the views of the Emperor. ==Early life== [[File:Fürst metternich.jpg|thumb|Metternich's coat of arms|250px]] Klemens Metternich was born into the [[House of Metternich]] on 15 May 1773 to Franz George Karl Count Metternich-[[County of Beilstein|Winneburg zu Beilstein]], a diplomat who had passed from the service of the [[Archbishopric of Trier]] to that of the Imperial court, and his wife Countess Maria Beatrice Aloisia von Kageneck.{{harvnb|Cecil|1947|pp=72–73}} He was named in honour of [[Prince Clemens Wenceslaus of Saxony]], the archbishop-elector of Trier and the past employer of his father.{{harvnb|Palmer|1972|pp=5–8}} He was the eldest son and had one older sister. At the time of his birth the family possessed a ruined keep at Beilstein, a castle at Winneberg, an estate west of [[Koblenz]], and another in [[Königswart]], [[Bohemia]], won during the 17th century. At this time Metternich's father, described as "a boring babbler and chronic liar" by a contemporary, was the Austrian ambassador to the courts of the three Rhenish electors (Trier, Cologne and Mainz). Metternich's education was handled by his mother, heavily influenced by their proximity to France; Metternich spoke French better than German. As a child he went on official visits with his father and, under the direction of Protestant tutor John Frederick Simon, was tutored in academic subjects, swimming, and horsemanship.{{harvnb|Palmer|1972|pp=10–12}}{{Cite journal|last=Nadeau|first=Ryan|date=2016|title=Creating a Statesman: The Early Life of Prince Clemens von Metternich and its Effect on his Political Philosophy|url=http://cupola.gettysburg.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1148&context=ghj|journal=The Gettysburg Historical Journal|volume=15|issue=1|pages=|issn=2327-3917|via=}} In the summer of 1788 Metternich began studying law at the [[University of Strasbourg]], matriculating on 12 November. While a student he was for some time accommodated by [[Maximilian I Joseph of Bavaria|Prince Maximilian of Zweibrücken]], the future King of Bavaria. At this time he was described by Simon as "happy, handsome and lovable", though contemporaries would later recount how he had been a liar and a braggart.{{harvnb|Palmer|1972|pp=12–16}} Metternich left Strasbourg in September 1790 to attend [[Leopold II, Holy Roman Emperor|Leopold II]]'s October coronation in [[Free City of Frankfurt|Frankfurt]], where he performed the largely honorific role of Ceremonial Marshall to the [[Bench of Counts of Westphalia|Catholic Bench of the College of the Counts of Westphalia]]. There, under the wing of his father, he met with the future [[Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor|Francis II]] and looked at ease among the attendant nobility. Between the end of 1790 and summer of 1792 Metternich studied law at the [[University of Mainz]],{{harvnb|Bertier de Sauvigny|1962|pp=xiii–xvii}} receiving a more conservative education than at Strasbourg, a city the return to which was now unsafe. In the summers he worked with his father, who had been appointed [[plenipotentiary]] and effective ruler of the [[Austrian Netherlands]]. In March 1792 Francis succeeded as Holy Roman Emperor and was crowned in July, affording Metternich a reprisal of his earlier role of Ceremonial Marshall. In the meantime France had declared war on Austria, beginning the [[War of the First Coalition]] (1792–7) and making Metternich's further study in Mainz impossible.{{harvnb|Palmer|1972|pp=16–22}} Now in the employment of his father, he was sent on a special mission to the front. Here he led the interrogation of the French Minister of War [[Pierre de Ruel, marquis de Beurnonville|the Marquis de Beurnonville]] and several accompanying [[National Convention]] commissioners. Metternich observed the [[Siege of Valenciennes (1793)|siege and fall of Valenciennes]], later looking back on these as substantial lessons about warfare. In early 1794 he was sent to England, ostensibly on official business helping [[Viscount Desandrouin]], by the Treasurer-General of the Austrian Netherlands, to negotiate a loan.{{harvnb|Palmer|1972|pp=22–25}} ==Marriage and the Congress of Rastatt== In England he met the King on several occasions and dined with a number of influential British politicians, including [[William Pitt the Younger|William Pitt]], [[Charles James Fox]] and [[Edmund Burke]].{{harvnb|Cecil|1947|p=76}} Metternich was nominated the new [[Minister Plenipotentiary]] to the [[Austrian Netherlands]] and left England in September 1794. On arrival, he found an exiled and powerless government in headlong retreat from the latest French advance. In October a revitalised French army swept into Germany and annexed all of the Metternich estates except Königswart. Disappointed, and affected by strong criticism of his father's policies, he joined his parents in Vienna in November.{{harvnb|Palmer|1972|pp=25–27}} On 27 September 1795 he married Countess Eleonore von Kaunitz, a granddaughter of former Austrian chancellor [[Wenzel Anton Graf Kaunitz|Wenzel Kaunitz]].{{harvnb|Cecil|1947|pp=78–79}} The marriage was arranged by Metternich's mother and introduced him to Viennese society. This was undoubtedly part of the motivation for Metternich, who demonstrated less affection for her than she for him. Two conditions were imposed by the father of the bride, Prince Kaunitz: first, the still youthful Eleonore was to continue to live at home; and second, Metternich was forbidden from serving as a diplomat as long as the Prince was still alive.
