In contrast, those who have attempted to rehabilitate Metternich describe him as “unquestionably [a] master of diplomacy”,{{harvnb|Ford|1971|p=281}} someone who perfected and indeed shaped the nature of diplomacy in his era.{{harvnb|Palmer|1972|pp=1–4}} In a similar vein, [[Alan Sked]] argues that Metternich’s “smokescreen” may well have served a purpose in furthering a relatively coherent set of principles. ==Issue== Metternich's children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren are (names are untranslated):{{harvnb|Palmer|1972|p=Family tree}}

{{ref improve|date=March 2013}} [[Image:Dr Frank by Press3.jpg|thumb|Dr. Konstantin Frank|400px|right]] Dr. '''Konstantin Frank''' (1899–1985) was a [[viticulture|viticulturist]] and [[winemaker]] in the [[Finger Lakes]] region of [[New York (state)|New York]]. He was born in [[Odessa]], [[Ukraine]] (then part of the [[Russian Empire]]) and received his PhD in [[viticulture]] from the Odessa Polytechnic Institute, his thesis being on techniques for growing ''[[Vitis vinifera]]'' in a cold climate. After working for a time in what was then [[Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic|Soviet Georgia]] managing a large state-owned vineyard, he came to the [[United States]] in 1951. Speaking nine languages, English not being one of them, Frank was forced to take a job as a dishwasher in [[New York City]]. When he could save up enough, Frank moved with his family to the [[Cornell University]] [[Geneva Experiment Station]] in 1953. During the 1950s, he was a consultant to the [[Gold Seal Winery]] and established a ''Vitis vinifera'' grape nursery.<ref name="nrhpinv_ny">{{cite web|url=http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=103596|title=National Register of Historic Places Registration: Gold Seal Winery|date=April 2010|accessdate=2012-08-05|author=Robert T. Englert|publisher=[[New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161003153754/http://www.oprhp.state.ny.us/hpimaging/hp_view.asp?GroupView=103596|archivedate=2016-10-03|df=}}</ref> He urged [[New York State]] winemakers to move away from native North American grapes, including ''[[Vitis labrusca]]'' and other species, and instead plant ''Vitis vinifera'', the traditional grapes of [[Europe]]an winemakers. For 300 years, failed attempts to plant "Vitis vinifera" varieties were blamed on the cold weather. With extensive experience growing the European grapes in below freezing temperatures back in [[Ukraine]], Frank knew it would be possible with the techniques that he developed.
His ideas were ridiculed. No one thought that ''Vitis vinifera'' would grow in cold [[Upstate New York]]. So in 1958 Frank bought a plot of land on the west side of [[Keuka Lake]], about six miles from Hammondsport, NY. The first vintage released was in 1962 with a [[Trockenbeerenauslese]] Johannisberg Riesling made from [[Botrytis cinerea|botrytized]] grapes. A scientist at heart, Frank, in the twenty-three years that he owned his winery, planted over sixty different varieties to prove to the world that the eastern United States could grow the noble European vinifera grape varieties. In 1985, Frank died at the age of 86. His legacy is cherished in New York, paving the way for other Finger Lakes producers to grow the European grape varieties. In November 2001, Konstantin Frank was inducted into the [[Wine Spectator]] Hall of Fame for his outstanding achievements in the field of viticulture.
Konstantin's son, Willy Frank, became President after his father's death and surprised some in the industry by introducing [[sparkling wines]] made in the traditional [[methode champenoise]] technique. He purchased a historic field stone house, then restored it into a sparkling winery and named it Chateau Frank. In 1993, Fred Frank, Konstantin's grandson, succeeded his father as President of Dr. Konstantin Frank Vinifera Wine Cellars. That same year, he introduced a value line called "Salmon Run" using grapes sourced from local farms around the Finger Lakes.

'''Laurent Louis "Larry" Desjardins''' (born March 15, 1923, in [[Saint Boniface, Winnipeg|St. Boniface]], [[Manitoba]] – February 7, 2012 in [[Winnipeg]], Manitoba <ref name="mort">{{cite web|url=http://www.radio-canada.ca/regions/manitoba/2012/02/08/002-deces-laurent-desjardins.shtml |title=L'ancien ministre provincial Laurent Desjardins est mort à l'âge de 88 ans | Manitoba |publisher=Radio-Canada.ca |date= |accessdate=2012-03-04 |language=French}}</ref> ) was a politician in [[Manitoba]], Canada. He served as a member of the [[Manitoba legislature]] for most of the period from 1959 to 1988,<ref name="Hebert2005">{{cite book|last=Hebert|first=Raymond M.|title=Manitoba's French-Language Crisis: A Cautionary Tale|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GNYl40r3NHsC&pg=PA18|accessdate=10 April 2011|date=2005|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press - MQUP|isbn=978-0-7735-2790-4|page=18}}</ref> and was a cabinet minister under [[New Democratic Party of Manitoba|New Democratic]] [[Premier]]s [[Edward Schreyer]] and [[Howard Pawley]].<ref name="gentle">{{cite web|author=Alan Hustak |url=http://v1.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20120303.OBDESJARDINS2ATL/BDAStory/BDA/deaths |title=globeandmail.com: Gentle giant of Manitoba politics championed French-language rights |publisher=V1.theglobeandmail.com |date=1923-03-15 |accessdate=2012-03-04}}</ref>
The son of Joseph A. Desjardins and Valentine Desautels,<ref name="normandin">{{cite book |title=Canadian Parliamentary Guide |year=1965 |last=Normandin |first=Pierre G}}</ref> Desjardins was educated at ''St. Boniface College'', ''St. Paul's College'' and the ''[[Cincinnati, Ohio|Cincinnati]] College of Embalming''. Desjardins played professional [[Canadian football|football]] with the [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]]. He was general manager of the St. Boniface Jr. Canadians and was a scout for the [[Montreal Canadiens]]. He was inducted into Manitoba’s sports hall of fame in 1990. He served in the Canadian navy during [[World War II]].<ref name="gentle"/> He worked as a funeral director, and was the President and Managing Director of ''Chapels, Ltd''. He also joined the [[Knights of Columbus]] and the [[Canadian Centre for Diversity|Canadian Council of Christian and Jews]] during the early years of his career.<ref name="mhs">{{cite web |url=http://www.mhs.mb.ca/docs/people/desjardins_ll.shtml |work=Memorable Manitobans |title=Laurent Louis "Larry" Desjardins (1923-2012) |publisher=[[Manitoba Historical Society]] |accessdate=2013-10-13}}</ref> In 1944, he married Bernice McGuire.<ref name="normandin"/>
Desjardins began his political career at the municipal level, serving as an [[alderman]] on the St. Boniface City Council from 1951 to 1954, and also serving on the St. Boniface Hospital Board for a number of years.<ref name="mhs"/> In the [[Manitoba general election, 1959|Manitoba general election of 1959]], he was elected to the Manitoba legislature in the riding of [[St. Boniface (Manitoba riding)|St. Boniface]] as a [[Liberal Party of Manitoba|Liberal-Progressive]]. This was the year of [[Progressive Conservative Party of Manitoba|Progressive Conservative]] Premier [[Dufferin Roblin]]'s first majority win, and Desjardins joined ten other Liberal-Progressives in the official opposition.<ref name="members"/>
In 1961, Desjardins emerged as one of the leading parliamentary supporters of government funding for private and denominational schools. A [[Roman Catholic]] and a [[francophone]], Desjardins regarded such funding as necessary for redressing anti-francophone legislation that had been pursued by previous Manitoba governments in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. The Roblin government took some steps on this front, but the issue was still unresolved by the 1970s.
Despite the Roblin government's popularity, Desjardins had little difficulty being returned in the elections of [[Manitoba general election, 1962|1962]] and [[Manitoba general election, 1966|1966]] (the Liberal-Progressives had changed their name to the [[Manitoba Liberal Party]] in 1961). In the [[Manitoba general election, 1969|election of 1969]], Desjardins faced stronger-than-usual competition from his New Democratic opponent (one [[Kam Gajdosik]]), but won by 4210 votes to 2656.
The 1969 election was a watershed in Manitoba politics, and resulted in a dramatic shift in Desjardins's career. Under Edward Schreyer's leadership, the [[social-democratic]] NDP moved from third to first place, winning 28 seats out of 57 in the assembly. This was one short of a majority, and there was initial uncertainty as to which party or parties would form government. There was some consideration of an "anti-socialist coalition", which would have brought together all parties except the NDP under the leadership of former Liberal leader [[Gildas Molgat]]. This, however, did not occur. The impasse was ended when Desjardians announced that he would offer parliamentary support to the NDP, and change his party affiliation to ''Liberal-Democrat''.
Desjardins's change of affiliation was significant, and on some levels surprising. He had previously been known as an opponent of [[socialism]], and Manitoba's francophone population had not traditionally been supportive of the New Democratic Party before this time. Nevertheless, Desjardins was able to form an alliance with Schreyer (himself a centrist New Democrat), on the understanding that he would be able to continue to work in favour of denominational school funding on the government side.
In order to make sure this move was supported by his constituents, Desjardins organized a vote of confidence on this decision on July 8. Had he lost this vote, Desjardins would have resigned as MLA, and would have run as a Liberal-Democrat candidate in a subsequent by-election. About 1000 people showed up at the Louis Riel School gymnasium for the vote of canfidence, and Desjardins received a standing ovation when he arrived in the hall. The vast majority of the attendees gave their support to Desjardins, with only 13 people opposing him.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Desjardins is supported in NDP move|last=|first=|date=July 9, 1969|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|access-date=|archive-url=|page=1|dead-url=}}</ref> Desjardins became Schreyer's legislative assistant in 1969, and formally joined the New Democratic Party in 1971.
On December 1, 1971, Desjardins was appointed [[Manitoba Minister of Tourism, Recreation and Cultural Affairs|Minister of Tourism, Recreation and Cultural Affairs]].<ref name="members"/> In July 1972, his efforts in support of denominational schools were dealt a setback when a government-sponsored bill to permit funding was defeated by a free vote in the legislature. (The Schreyer government did, however, make administrative agreements with certain private schools to provide them with access to public monies.)
Given the lack of historical francophone support for the NDP in Manitoba, it was unclear if Desjardins would be re-elected in the [[Manitoba general election, 1973|provincial election of 1973]], and his riding was targeted by a right-wing "citizen's" group in the amalgamated city of [[Winnipeg]] (which included St. Boniface). This group convinced the Progressive Conservative Party to withdraw their candidate in St. Boniface, so as to provide a single "anti-socialist" alternative to the NDP.
Desjardins's sole opponent in June 1973 was Liberal candidate [[J. Paul Marion]]. Following a very close race, Marion was declared the winner by a single vote (4301 to 4300). This result was disputed, however, and was subsequently overturned by the [[Controverted Elections Act]]. In December 1974, Desjardins defeated Marion in a by-election<ref name="members"/> by over 600 votes.
Schreyer's New Democrats were re-elected in the 1973 campaign. Desjardins had resigned from cabinet on January 28, 1974, during the ongoing controversy concerning the St. Boniface results, but on December 23, 1974, he was re-admitted to cabinet as [[Manitoba Minister of Health and Social Development|Minister of Health and Social Development]]. On January 8, 1975, he was also given responsibility for the [[Manitoba Lotteries Act (Manitoba ministry)|Manitoba Lotteries Act]].<ref name="members"/>
Desjardins was easily re-elected in the [[Manitoba general election, 1977|1977 election]], although Schreyer's New Democrats were defeated provincially by the Progressive Conservatives under [[Sterling Lyon]]. Desjardins sat as a member of the opposition for the next four years.
The New Democrats were returned to power in the [[Manitoba general election, 1981|provincial election of 1981]] under the leadership of [[Howard Pawley]], and Desjardins was personally re-elected without difficulty. He was re-appointed to cabinet on November 30, 1981, serving as [[Manitoba Minister of Health|Minister of Health]] and [[Manitoba Minister of Recreation and Sport|Minister of Recreation and Sport]], with responsibility for the [[Lotteries and Gaming Control Act (Manitoba ministry)|Lotteries and Gaming Control Act]]. He was re-designated as Minister of Health with responsibility for [[Minister responsible for Sport, the Fitness and Amateur Sport Act, and the Boxing and Wrestling Commission Act (Manitoba)|Minister responsible for Sport, the Fitness and Amateur Sport Act, and the Boxing and Wrestling Commission Act]] and the [[Manitoba Lotteries Foundation Act (Manitoba ministry)|Manitoba Lotteries Foundation Act]].<ref name="members"/>
During the 1980s, Desjardins was a prominent supporter of Howard Pawley's efforts to expand and entrench French-language services in Manitoba.
On January 30, 1985, Desjardins was shifted to the [[Manitoba Minister of Urban Affairs|Ministry of Urban Affairs]]. He was again re-elected without difficulty in the [[Manitoba general election, 1986|1986 provincial election]], and on April 17, 1986, he was re-appointed [[Manitoba Minister of Health and Sport|Minister of Health and Sport]] (once again holding responsibility for the Boxing and Wrestling Commission Act and the Fitness and Amateur Sport Act).<ref name="members">{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.mb.ca/hansard/members/mla_bio_deceased.html#D0 |title=MLA Biographies - Deceased |work=Legislative Assembly of Manitoba |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140330155427/http://www.gov.mb.ca/hansard/members/mla_bio_deceased.html |archivedate=2014-03-30 |df= }}</ref>
Desjardins resigned from his cabinet positions on February 10, 1988, after a Supreme Court ruling that provinces could not restrict a woman's right to abortion,<ref name="gentle"/> and announced that he would be leaving the legislature to take a job in the private sector. His seat was not formally declared vacant, but he stopped attending sessions of the legislature after this period. He then served as head of the Manitoba Health Organization until 1990.<ref name="mort"/>
Ironically, just as Desjardins had helped bring the NDP into government in 1969, his decision to leave the legislature in 1988 played a major role in the party's unexpected fall from power. In his absence, the legislature was almost evenly divided between government and opposition members; as such, NDP backbencher [[Jim Walding]]'s decision to vote against his government's budget was enough to defeat the Pawley ministry in the house.<ref name="gentle"/> The NDP lost the election which followed, and did not return to power until 1999.
During his time in the legislature, Desjardins was known as a personable figure (fellow New Democratic cabinet minister [[Russell Doern]] once called him a "[[Rabelais|Rabelasian]] character"). He was regarded as cautious and pragmatic, and was often more supportive of small-business interests than others in the New Democratic Party. Desjardins was a member of the federal [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal Party]] for most, if not all of time in the provincial NDP. This practice is no longer possible; the federal NDP is now integrated with its provincial and territorial branches. He openly supported Liberal [[Lloyd Axworthy]]'s successful bid to enter the [[House of Commons of Canada]] in 1979.<ref name="gentle"/>
During the 1990s, Desjardins led a policy review group which studied Manitoba's lotteries system, and argued against the expansion of Manitoba's [[casino]] economy. In 2002, he wrote an open letter on health-care reform in, arguing that money alone would not resolve the problems within the system. In March 2003, he participated in a discussion on health-care funding at the ''Frontier Centre for Public Policy'', in which he argued that Canada's provinces should be permitted to enact user fees and expand the role of the private sector in health-care provision. He served as first president of the [[Western Canada Lottery Corporation|Western Canada Lottery Foundation]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.halloffame.mb.ca/honoured/1990/lDesjardins.htm |title=Larry Desjardins |publisher=Manitoba Sports Hall of Fame |accessdate=2013-10-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014192046/http://www.halloffame.mb.ca/honoured/1990/lDesjardins.htm |archivedate=2013-10-14 |df= }}</ref>
Desjardins died at the [[Victoria General Hospital (Winnipeg)|Victoria Hospital]] in Winnipeg following a fall.<ref name="mort"/>

{{Use Australian English|date=August 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''The X Factor'' finalists (Australia season 5)}} The [[The X Factor (Australia season 5)|fifth season]] of ''[[The X Factor (Australian TV series)|The X Factor Australia]]'' premiered on the [[Seven Network]] on 29 July 2013 and ended on 28 October 2013.<ref>{{cite web|last=B|first=Alicia|url=http://www.throng.com.au/2013/07/the-x-factor-starts-monday-29th-july-on-seven/|title=The X Factor Starts Monday 29th July on Seven|publisher=Throng. Throng Media|date=16 July 2013|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref><ref name="Grand Final">{{cite web|url=http://www.take40.com/news/43062/the-x-factor-grand-final-2013---dami-im-is-crowned-the-winner! |title=The X Factor Grand Final 2013 – Dami Im Crowned The Winner! |publisher=[[Take 40 Australia]]. MCM Entertainment |date=28 October 2013 |accessdate=28 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131030052203/http://www.take40.com/news/43062/the-x-factor-grand-final-2013---dami-im-is-crowned-the-winner%21 |archivedate=30 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> The judging panel consisted of [[Ronan Keating]], [[Redfoo]], [[Natalie Bassingthwaighte]] and [[Dannii Minogue]]. Keating mentored the Under 24 Boys, Redfoo mentored the Under 24 Girls, Bassingthwaighte mentored the Groups and Minogue mentored the Over 24s.<ref name="Top 12">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/news/article/-/18581266/the-x-factor-reveals-the-top-12-ahead-of-live-shows/|title=The X Factor reveals the Top 12 ahead of live shows|work=[[The X Factor (Australian TV series)|The X Factor Australia]]|publisher=[[Yahoo!7]]|accessdate=21 August 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130823180015/http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/news/article/-/18581266/the-x-factor-reveals-the-top-12-ahead-of-live-shows/|archivedate=23 August 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Dami Im]] was declared the winner, with Minogue emerging as the winning mentor for the first time on the Australian version.<ref name="Grand Final"/>
==Under 24 Boys==
===Omar Dean===
Omar Dean was a 20-year-old contestant from [[Melbourne]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]<ref name="Top 12"/> who auditioned for ''The X Factor'' singing "[[Climax (Usher song)|Climax]]" by [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]].<ref name="Omar Profile">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584659/omar-dean/|title=Omar Dean|work=The X Factor Australia|publisher=Yahoo!7|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> Dean stated that his "own desire and passion" and encouragement from family and friends inspired him to audition.<ref name="Omar Profile"/> At the age of 15, Dean was bullied at school for being overweight.<ref name="Omar TV Week">{{cite journal|last=|first=|date=28 September – 4 October 2013|title=Losing to Win|journal=[[TV Week]]|publisher=[[Bauer Media Group]]|issue=39|pages=8–9}}</ref> He turned to music to cope with the bullying.<ref name="X Factor Profiles">{{cite news|last=Adams|first=Cameron|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/television/x-factor-reveals-final-top-12-to-perform-at-live-shows/story-fni0cc2c-1226700919850|title=X Factor reveals final Top 12 to perform at live shows|work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=[[News Limited]]|date=21 August 2013|accessdate=22 August 2013}}</ref> Dean's mother Rania then sent him to the United States to start a health kick.<ref name="Omar TV Week"/> He later returned to Australia as "a completely different person."<ref name="Omar TV Week"/> Dean cites Usher, [[Justin Bieber]] and [[Justin Timberlake]] as his musical influences.<ref name="Omar Profile"/> Dean landed in the final showdown in week seven with [[Jiordan Tolli]] after receiving the fewest public votes.<ref name="Week 7 Elimination">{{cite web|last=B|first=Alicia|url=http://www.throng.com.au/2013/10/the-x-factor-says-goodbye-to-ronans-omar-dean/|title=The X Factor Says Goodbye To Ronan's Omar Dean|publisher=Throng. Throng Media|date=7 October 2013|accessdate=7 October 2013}}</ref> He was eventually eliminated from the competition after the judges decision went to deadlock, and he received the fewest votes, finishing sixth.<ref name="Week 7 Elimination"/>
===Taylor Henderson=== {{main|Taylor Henderson}} [[File:Taylor Henderson 2013.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Taylor Henderson]] Taylor Henderson was a 20-year-old contestant from [[Ceres, Victoria]]<ref name="Live show 1">{{cite episode |title=Season 5, Episode 13: Live show 1|series=The X Factor Australia |network=[[Seven Network]] |airdate=25 August 2013}}</ref> who sang "[[Some Nights (song)|Some Nights]]" by [[Fun (band)|Fun]] at his audition.<ref name="Taylor Profile">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584676/taylor-henderson/|title=Taylor Henderson|work=The X Factor Australia|publisher=Yahoo!7|accessdate=21 August 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KdRdvy8M?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584676/taylor-henderson/|archivedate=25 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Henderson stated that his family inspired him to audition for ''The X Factor''.<ref name="Taylor Profile"/> Henderson plays guitar and writes his own songs.<ref name="X Factor Profiles"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Midwood|first=Tim|url=http://www.upstart.net.au/2011/12/05/interview-with-musician-taylor-henderson/|title=Interview with musician Taylor Henderson|publisher=Upstart|date=5 December 2011|accessdate=22 August 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021064857/http://www.upstart.net.au/2011/12/05/interview-with-musician-taylor-henderson/|archivedate=21 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He cites [[Matt Corby]], [[Michael Jackson]], [[John Mayer]], [[James Morrison (singer)|James Morrison]], [[Jason Mraz]], [[Ed Sheeran]] and Justin Timberlake as his musical influences.<ref name="Taylor Profile"/> Henderson was born with [[Marcus Gunn phenomenon|Marcus Gunn Jaw-winking Syndrome]].<ref name="Taylor TV Week">{{cite journal|last=Goldstein|first=Sharon|date=31 August – 6 September 2013|title=Career or Cult|journal=TV Week|publisher=Bauer Media Group|issue=35|page=22}}</ref> He lived with his father Cameron and his two sisters Bridey and Gemma on a farm.<ref name="Live show 1"/><ref name="Taylor TV Week"/> Henderson and Cameron were finalists in the [[Australia's Got Talent (series 4)|fourth series]] of ''[[Australia's Got Talent]]''; Henderson finished in third place and Cameron was runner-up.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/celebrity/australias-got-talent-finalist-taylor-henderson-forced-to-choose-tv-stardom-or-geelong-church/story-e6frf96o-1225880976537|title=Australia's Got Talent finalist Taylor Henderson forced to choose TV stardom or Geelong church|work=[[Herald Sun]]|publisher=[[The Herald and Weekly Times]]|date=17 June 2010|accessdate=22 August 2013}}</ref> Prior to entering ''The X Factor'', he worked as a labourer.<ref name="X Factor Profiles"/> After Henderson became the runner-up to [[Dami Im]], he received a recording contract with [[Sony Music Australia]].<ref name="Signed to Sony">{{cite news|last=McCabe|first=Kathy|url=http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/music/x-factor-stars-taylor-jai-and-third-d3gree-to-release-singles-today/story-e6frfn09-1226750712131|title=X Factor stars Taylor, Jai and Third Degree to release singles today|work=News.com.au|publisher=News Limited|date=1 November 2013|accessdate=3 November 2013}}</ref>
===Jai Waetford=== {{main|Jai Waetford}} [[File:Jai Waetford.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Jai Waetford]] Jai Waetford was a 14-year-old contestant from [[Campbelltown, New South Wales]]<ref name="Jai Daily Telegraph Interview"/> who sang two songs at his audition. The first was "Different Worlds" by Jes Hudak and the second was an original song titled "Don't Let Me Go".<ref name="Jai Profile">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584572/jai-waetford/ |title=Jai Waetford |work=The X Factor Australia |publisher=Yahoo!7 |accessdate=21 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131027085438/http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584572/jai-waetford/ |archivedate=27 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> Waetford's family and friends inspired him to audition for ''The X Factor''.<ref name="Jai Profile"/> He lived with his mother Alana Dow and grandparents Hannah and Roger Dow.<ref name="Jai Who Interview">{{cite web|last=Braithwaite |first=Alyssa |url=http://au.lifestyle.yahoo.com/who/latest-news/article/-/18275081/x-factors-jai-waetford-i-wont-let-fame-go-to-my-head/ |title=X Factor's Jai Waetford: I won't let fame go to my head |work=[[Who (magazine)|Who]] |publisher=[[Pacific Magazines]] |date=1 August 2013 |accessdate=22 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130807210503/http://au.lifestyle.yahoo.com/who/latest-news/article/-/18275081/x-factors-jai-waetford-i-wont-let-fame-go-to-my-head/ |archivedate=7 August 2013 |df= }}</ref> Waetford's father, who moved to [[Switzerland]], left him and his mother when he was young.<ref name="Jai Daily Telegraph Interview">{{cite news|last=Moran|first=Jonathan|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/jai-waetford-may-look-like-justin-bieber-but-this-teen-has-his-own-talent/story-fni0cvc9-1226679141267|title=Jai Waetford may look like Justin Bieber but this teen has his own talent|work=The Daily Telegraph|publisher=News Limited|date=14 July 2013|accessdate=22 August 2013}}</ref><ref name="Jai TV Week">{{cite journal|last=Giles|first=Amber|date=10–16 August 2013|title=Jai's Secret Love|journal=TV Week|publisher=Bauer Media Group|issue=32|page=10}}</ref> However, they still keep in contact.<ref name="Jai TV Week"/> Waetford has been compared by many to Justin Bieber.<ref name="Jai Daily Telegraph Interview"/><ref name="Jai Who Interview"/> He plays guitar and writes his own songs.<ref name="Jai Who Interview"/> Waetford taught himself how to play guitar from watching videos on [[YouTube]].<ref name="X Factor Profiles"/> He cites Justin Bieber, Michael Jackson, [[Bruno Mars]], [[Elvis Presley]], [[Guy Sebastian]] and [[Stevie Wonder]] as his musical influences.<ref name="Jai Profile"/> Prior to entering ''The X Factor'', Waetford was a student at [[Campbelltown Performing Arts High School]].<ref name="Jai Daily Telegraph Interview"/> He placed third in the competition and received a recording contract with Sony Music Australia.<ref name="Signed to Sony"/>
==Under 24 Girls==
===Joelle Hadjia=== {{main|Joelle Hadjia}} [[File:Joelle Hadjia.jpg|thumb|right|150px|Joelle Hadjia]] Joelle Hadjia was a 22-year-old contestant from Sydney, New South Wales<ref name="Top 12"/> who sang "[[Don't You Worry Child]]" by [[Swedish House Mafia]] at her audition.<ref name="Joelle Profile">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584626/joelle/|title=Joelle|work=The X Factor Australia|publisher=Yahoo!7|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> Hadjia previously auditioned in the [[The X Factor (Australia season 4)|fourth season]] as a member of the female duo Good Question, who were eliminated during the [[The X Factor (Australia season 4)#Home visits|home visits]] stage.<ref name="X Factor Profiles"/> She cites [[Beyoncé]], [[Drake (entertainer)|Drake]], [[Rihanna]], [[The Weeknd]], [[Chris Brown (American entertainer)|Chris Brown]], [[Lauryn Hill]], [[Keri Hilson]], [[Jessie J]], [[John Legend]], [[Rita Ora]], [[Kelly Rowland]], Ed Sheeran and [[Taylor Swift]] as her musical influences.<ref name="Joelle Profile"/> Prior to entering ''The X Factor'', Hadjia was a student at the [[University of Western Sydney]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uws.edu.au/newscentre/news_centre/more_news_stories/uws_student_returns_to_x-factor|title=UWS student returns to X Factor|publisher=[[University of Western Sydney]]|date=25 July 2013|accessdate=22 August 2013}}</ref> She dated [[South Sydney Rabbitohs]] rugby league player [[Sam Burgess]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/rabbitoh-hottie-sam-burgess-seeking-x-factor-in-his-love-life/story-fni0cvc9-1226705268026|title=Rabbitoh hottie Sam Burgess seeking X Factor in his love life|work=The Daily Telegraph|publisher=News Limited|date=28 August 2013|accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref> Hadjia was in the bottom two in the second week of the live shows, alongside Cat Vas.<ref name="Week 2 Elimination">{{cite web|url=http://www.take40.com/news/42056/the-x-factor-australia---cat-vas-is-sent-home!- |title=The X Factor Australia – Cat Vas Is Sent Home! |publisher=[[Take 40 Australia]]. MCM Entertainment |date=2 September 2013 |accessdate=3 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130913012813/http://www.take40.com/news/42056/the-x-factor-australia---cat-vas-is-sent-home%21- |archivedate=13 September 2013 |df= }}</ref> She was saved from elimination after Keating, Bassingthwaighte and Redfoo all voted to send Vas home.<ref name="Week 2 Elimination"/> Hadjia was again in the bottom two with Jiordan Tolli in week five, both acts from Redfoo's category.<ref name="Week 5 elimination">{{cite web|url=http://www.take40.com/news/42450/the-x-factor-australia-live-decider---joelle-is-sent-home-after-redfoo's-girls-face-off!|title=The X Factor Australia Live Decider – Joelle Is Sent Home After RedFoo's Girls Face Off!|publisher=Take 40 Australia. MCM Entertainment|date=24 September 2013|accessdate=25 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926190028/http://www.take40.com/news/42450/the-x-factor-australia-live-decider---joelle-is-sent-home-after-redfoo's-girls-face-off!|archivedate=26 September 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This time, she was eliminated, placing eighth.<ref name="Week 5 elimination"/>
===Ellie Lovegrove=== Ellie Lovegrove (born 17 April 1994)<ref name="Ellie Profile">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584450/ellie-lovegrove/|title=Ellie Lovegrove|work=The X Factor Australia|publisher=Yahoo!7|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> was a 19-year-old contestant from [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]]<ref name="Top 12"/> who auditioned for ''The X Factor'' singing "[[Girl on Fire (song)|Girl on Fire]]" by [[Alicia Keys]].<ref name="Ellie Profile"/> Lovegrove is an [[Indigenous Australian]] and a descendant of the [[Ngarrindjeri]] nation.<ref name="Ellie Vibe Interview">{{cite web|url=http://www.vibe.com.au/news/ellies-got-the-x-factor|title=Ellie's got the X Factor|work=[[Vibe Australia]]|publisher=|date=16 August 2013|accessdate=22 August 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130927190417/http://www.vibe.com.au/news/ellies-got-the-x-factor|archivedate=27 September 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She has four older brothers.<ref name="Ellie Profile"/> Her father, who died when she was 10 years old, was a country music singer and inspired her passion for music.<ref name="Ellie Vibe Interview"/> Lovegrove began performing country music at the age of 12.<ref name="Ellie Vibe Interview"/> She cites Beyoncé, [[Casey Donovan (singer)|Casey Donovan]], [[Jessica Mauboy]], [[Archie Roach]] and [[Gurrumul Yunupingu]] as her musical influences.<ref name="Ellie Profile"/><ref name="Ellie Vibe Interview"/> Prior to entering ''The X Factor'', Lovegrove was a university student and did a lot of volunteering for the Aboriginal community.<ref name="X Factor Profiles"/> Lovegrove landed in the final showdown in week four with JTR after receiving the fewest public votes.<ref name="Week 4 Elimination"/> She was eventually eliminated from the competition after the judges decision went to deadlock, and she received the fewest votes, finishing ninth.<ref name="Week 4 Elimination">{{cite web|url=http://www.take40.com/news/42303/the-x-factor-australia---ellie-lovegrove-is-eliminated-from-the-competition|title=The X Factor Australia – Ellie Lovegrove is Eliminated From the Competition|publisher=Take 40 Australia. MCM Entertainment|date=16 September 2013|accessdate=17 September 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130917191042/http://www.take40.com/news/42303/the-x-factor-australia---ellie-lovegrove-is-eliminated-from-the-competition|archivedate=17 September 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Jiordan Tolli=== {{main|Jiordan Tolli}} Jiordan Tolli was a 19-year-old contestant from Melbourne, Victoria<ref name="Top 12"/> who sang [[Birdy (musician)|Birdy]]'s version of "[[People Help the People#Birdy version|People Help the People]]" at her audition.<ref name="Jiordan Profile">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584615/jiordan-tolli/|title=Jiordan Tolli|work=The X Factor Australia|publisher=Yahoo!7|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> Tolli's mother inspired her to audition for ''The X Factor''.<ref name="Jiordan Profile"/> She cites Birdy, [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]], [[Lorde]], [[Lana Del Rey]] and [[Norah Jones]] as her musical influences.<ref name="Jiordan Profile"/> From 1994 to 2001, Tolli played [[Lolly Allen|Louise "Lolly" Carpenter]] on the Australian soap opera ''[[Neighbours]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Te Koha|first=Nui|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/neighbours-child-star-jiodan-tolli-who-played-lolly-carpenter-on-ramsay-st-returns-to-our-screens-on-x-factor/story-fni0fit3-1226691684673|title=Neighbours child star Jiordan Tolli, who played Lolly Carpenter on Ramsay St, returns to our screens on X Factor|work=Herald Sun|publisher=The Herald and Weekly Times|date=5 August 2013|accessdate=22 August 2013}}</ref> Prior to entering ''The X Factor'', she performed in a lot of musical theatre.<ref name="X Factor Profiles"/> In week five of the live shows, Tolli fell into the bottom two alongside [[Joelle Hadjia]] but was saved after Keating, Bassingthwaighte and Minogue all opted to eliminate Hadjia.<ref name="Week 5 elimination"/> Following the eliminations of Hadjia and Ellie Lovegrove, Tolli became the only remaining contestant in the Under 24 Girls category. She was in the final showdown again in week seven with Omar Dean and after the judges decision went to deadlock, it was revealed that Dean received the fewest votes and was eliminated.<ref name="Week 7 Elimination"/> Tolli was eventually eliminated from the competition in week eight, after the judges decision went to deadlock, and she received the fewest votes, finishing fifth.<ref name="Week 8 Elimination">{{cite web|url=http://www.take40.com/news/42808/the-x-factor-australia-recap---jiordan-tolli-sent-home-after-facing-off-with-third-d3gree!|title=The X Factor Australia 2013 – Jiordan Tolli Sent Home After Facing Off With Third D3gree!|publisher=Take 40 Australia. MCM Entertainment|date=14 October 2013|accessdate=14 October 2013}}</ref>
==Over 24s==
===Dami Im=== {{main|Dami Im}} [[File:Dami Im.jpg|thumb|right|160px|Dami Im]] Dami Im was a 24-year-old contestant from [[Daisy Hill, Queensland]]<ref name="Dami JTR">{{cite news|last=Masters|first=Stephanie|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/questnews/xfactor8217s-dami-im-to-the-fore-as-logan-dominates-tv-talent-quests/story-fni9r0hy-1226709173552|title=X-Factor's Dami Im to the fore as Logan dominates TV talent quests|work=[[Quest Community Newspapers]]|publisher=[[News Corporation]]|date=3 September 2013|accessdate=6 September 2013}}</ref> who sang "[[Hero (Mariah Carey song)|Hero]]" by [[Mariah Carey]] at her audition.<ref name="Dami Profile">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584428/dami-im/ |title=Dami Im |work=The X Factor Australia |publisher=Yahoo!7 |accessdate=21 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KZeIlZEp?url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584428/dami-im/ |archivedate=23 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> Im was initially a contestant in the Under 25 Girls category, however, once the minimum age for the Overs category was changed from 25 to 24, she became part of the newly formed Over 24s category. Im was initially eliminated during the [[The X Factor (Australia season 5)#Super bootcamp|super bootcamp]] stage, but was called back for the [[The X Factor (Australia season 5)#Home visits|home visits]] to replace Matt Gresham who decided he could not commit to the competition.<ref>{{cite episode|title=Season 5, Episode 10: Home visits|series=The X Factor Australia|network=Seven Network|airdate=18 August 2013}}</ref> She was born in [[South Korea]] and migrated to Australia at the age of nine, with her mother and younger brother.<ref name="Dami Profile"/><ref name="Dami The Age">{{cite news|last=Sams |first=Christine |url=http://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/some-people-thought-i-was-stupid-x-factor-star-dami-recalls-terrible-childhood-20130829-2sshi.html |title='Some people thought I was stupid': X Factor star Dami recalls terrible childhood |work=[[The Age]] |publisher=[[Fairfax Media]] |date=29 August 2013 |accessdate=2 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KZeNcyFY?url=http://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/some-people-thought-i-was-stupid-x-factor-star-dami-recalls-terrible-childhood-20130829-2sshi.html |archivedate=23 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> Im's father stayed in South Korea to send the family money.<ref name="Dami The Age"/> Her parents now live together, spending part of the year in Australia and part in South Korea.<ref name="Dami The Age"/> At the age of 11, Im began studying at the [[Queensland Conservatorium Griffith University|Young Conservatorium of Music]] program at [[Griffith University]].<ref name="Piano Competition"/> She attended [[John Paul College (Brisbane)|John Paul College]] in Daisy Hill and graduated in 2005.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bochenski |first=Natalie |url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/dami-ims-former-school-joins-the-dami-army-20130902-2t0yb.html |title=X-Factor's Dami Im Gains Support From Former School |work=[[Brisbane Times]] |publisher=Fairfax Digital |date=3 September 2013 |accessdate=3 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KZeSYsBV?url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/dami-ims-former-school-joins-the-dami-army-20130902-2t0yb.html |archivedate=23 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> Im is a member of the Brisbane Full Gospel Church in [[Eight Mile Plains, Queensland]].<ref name="Dami Church">{{cite news|last=Bochenski |first=Natalie |url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/holy-spirit-behind-angelic-voice-20130909-2tgac.html |title=Holy spirit behind Dami Im's angelic voice |work=Brisbane Times |publisher=Fairfax Digital |date=9 September 2013 |accessdate=12 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KZeXAhlA?url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/holy-spirit-behind-angelic-voice-20130909-2tgac.html |archivedate=23 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> In 2010, she released an album titled ''Dream'', which was recorded to raise money for church endeavours.<ref name="Dami Church"/> Im met Noah Kim, a former Korean military serviceman, at the church and they were married in [[Seoul]] in late 2012.<ref name="Dami Church"/>
Aside from singing, Im is also a violin player and pianist.<ref name="Dami Profile"/><ref name="Dami Church"/> She became the National Finalist of the Yamaha Youth Piano Competition, and won the Nora Baird Scholarship and the Queensland Piano Competition several times.<ref name="Piano Competition">{{cite web|url=http://www.lev-vlassenko.com/content/view/176/82/ |title=Dami Im |publisher=The Lev Vlassenko Piano Competition |accessdate=22 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6KZec7apT?url=http://www.lev-vlassenko.com/content/view/176/82/ |archivedate=23 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> In 2009, Im graduated from the [[University of Queensland]] with first class honours for her Bachelor of Music.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uq.edu.au/music/index.html?page=200618&pid=138103 |title=UQ Alumni Dami Im: X Factor |publisher=[[University of Queensland]] |accessdate=22 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029193108/http://www.uq.edu.au/music/index.html?page=200618&pid=138103 |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df= }}</ref> She cites Beyoncé, Mariah Carey, Norah Jones, [[Corinne Bailey Rae]] and [[Chris Tomlin]] as her musical influences.<ref name="Dami Profile"/> Prior to entering ''The X Factor'', Im was a music and piano teacher.<ref name="X Factor Profiles"/> Following the eliminations of Cat Vas and Barry Southgate, Im became the only remaining contestant in the Over 24s category. She was announced as the winner on 28 October 2013, and received a recording contract with Sony Music Australia.<ref name="Signed to Sony"/>
===Barry Southgate=== [[File:Barry Southgate (8138005422).jpg|thumb|right|140px|Barry Southgate]] Barry Southgate was a 30-year-old contestant from [[Kellyville, New South Wales]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Machado|first=Lawrence|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/local-singer-barry-southgate-makes-x-factor8217s-top-12/story-e6frf7jo-1226701124972?from=newslocal_rss|title=Local singer Barry Southgate makes X Factor's Top 12|work=Herald Sun|publisher=The Herald and Weekly Times|date=21 August 2013|accessdate=22 August 2013}}</ref> who auditioned for ''The X Factor'' singing "[[Let's Stay Together (Al Green song)|Let's Stay Together]]" by [[Al Green]].<ref name="Barry Profile">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584386/barry-southgate/|title=Barry Southgate|work=The X Factor Australia|publisher=Yahoo!7|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> Southgate stated that his second mother Audrey Phillips, who had terminal cancer at the time, inspired him to audition.<ref name="Barry Profile"/> Southgate is of [[Ethnic groups of Africa|African]], [[English people|English]], [[Germans|German]] and [[Indonesia]]n descent.<ref name="Barry Bio">{{cite web|last=Rene|first=Krystina|url=http://www.musicsrisingstarsmag.com/february2009/4.html|title=Barry Southgate|publisher=Music's Rising Stars Magazine|date=February 2009|accessdate=3 September 2013}}</ref> He was born in [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]] and moved to [[New Zealand]], with his parents and two younger brothers, during his teenage years.<ref name="Barry Bio"/> In 2003, Southgate moved to Sydney as part of the singing and dancing group Jireh.<ref name="Barry Bio"/> The group disbanded in 2004, and later that year Southgate was a top 30 finalist on the [[Australian Idol (season 2)|second season]] of ''[[Australian Idol]]''.<ref name="Barry Bio"/> In 2012, he auditioned for the [[The Voice (Australia series 1)|first season]] of ''[[The Voice (Australia)|The Voice Australia]]'', and appeared in the musical film ''[[The Sapphires (film)|The Sapphires]]'' as a singing sailor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australiaatcannes.com/pdf/Press-Kit_Sapphires.pdf|title=The Sapphires Press Kit|format=PDF|publisher=Australia at Cannes|accessdate=22 August 2013}}</ref> Southgate cites [[Boyz II Men]], Michael Jackson, Bruno Mars, [[Richard Marx]], [[Brian McKnight]], Justin Timberlake and Stevie Wonder as his musical influences.<ref name="Barry Profile"/> Prior to entering ''The X Factor'', he was a vocal teacher and performed as an opening act for [[Joe (singer)|Joe]], [[Eric Benét]], Brian McKnight and [[Tinie Tempah]].<ref name="X Factor Profiles"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://barrysouthgate.com/2012/03/11/love-from-the-motherland/|title=Love From the Motherland|publisher=Barry Southgate Official Site|date=11 March 2012|accessdate=22 August 2013}}</ref> Southgate landed in the final showdown in week one with Adira-Belle after receiving the fewest public votes, but was saved by Keating, Minogue and Redfoo.<ref name="Week 1 Elimination">{{cite web|last=B|first=Alicia|url=http://www.throng.com.au/2013/08/the-x-factor-first-elimination-goodbye/|title=The X Factor First Elimination – Goodbye Adira Belle|publisher=Throng. Throng Media|date=26 August 2013|accessdate=27 August 2013}}</ref> Southgate was in the final showdown again in week three with JTR and was eventually eliminated from the competition after Keating, Bassingthwaighte and Redfoo chose to save JTR.<ref name="Week 3 Elimination">{{cite web|url=http://www.take40.com/news/42178/the-x-factor-australia---barry-southgate-is-sent-home! |title=The X Factor Australia – Barry Southgate Is Sent Home! |publisher=Take 40 Australia. MCM Entertainment |date=9 September 2013 |accessdate=10 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130913012209/http://www.take40.com/news/42178/the-x-factor-australia---barry-southgate-is-sent-home%21 |archivedate=13 September 2013 |df= }}</ref>
===Cat Vas=== Cat Vas was a 27-year-old contestant who sang "[[Unchained Melody#The Righteous Brothers' version|Unchained Melody]]" by [[The Righteous Brothers]] at her audition.<ref name="Cat Profile">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584409/cat-vas/|title=Cat Vas|work=The X Factor Australia|publisher=Yahoo!7|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> Vas stated that hearing series four winner [[Samantha Jade]]'s story about "trying to crack the music industry for ages" inspired her to audition for ''The X Factor''.<ref name="Cat Profile"/> Vas is originally from Adelaide, South Australia but moved to Sydney, New South Wales.<ref name="Cat Profile"/> She is a Greek Australian and is the daughter of a minister.<ref name="X Factor Profiles"/><ref name="Live show 1"/> From the age of four to 16, Vas suffered from an [[immune disorder]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Giles|first=Amber|date=17–23 August 2013|title=Bullied and All Alone|journal=TV Week|publisher=Bauer Media Group|issue=33|page=6}}</ref> She cites [[Feist (singer)|Feist]], [[Haim (band)|Haim]], [[Robyn]], [[Lykke Li]], [[Katy Perry]] and [[Regina Spektor]] as her musical influences.<ref name="Cat Profile"/> Prior to entering ''The X Factor'', Vas was a music teacher.<ref name="X Factor Profiles"/> Vas landed in the final showdown in week two with Joelle Hadjia after receiving the fewest public votes.<ref name="Week 2 Elimination"/> She was eventually eliminated from the competition after Keating, Bassingthwaighte and Redfoo chose to save Hadjia.<ref name="Week 2 Elimination"/>
==Groups==
===Adira-Belle=== Adira-Belle were a four-member girl group that consisted of Kia (aged 17 from Sydney, New South Wales),<ref name="Adira-Belle Profile">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584376/adira-belle/|title=Adira-Belle|work=The X Factor Australia|publisher=Yahoo!7|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> Naomie (aged 19 from Sydney, New South Wales),<ref name="Adira-Belle Profile"/> Evelyn Evbuomwan (aged 19 from [[Glenwood, New South Wales]])<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/west/glenwood-girl-evelyn-evbuomwan-joins-xfactor-with-adirabelle/story-fngr8i5s-1226702071247?from=newslocal_rss|title=Glenwood girl Evelyn Evbuomwan joins X-Factor with Adira-Belle|work=Blacktown Advocate|publisher=News Limited|date=22 August 2013|accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref> and Temy Ntshangase (aged 17 from Campbelltown, New South Wales).<ref name="Temy Bio">{{cite news|last=Spencer|first=Lochlan|url=http://www.macarthuradvertiser.com.au/story/1672074/campbelltown-pair-wow-on-the-x-factor/|title=Campbelltown pair wow on The X Factor|work=Campelltown-Macarthur Advertiser|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=30 July 2013|accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref> Adira-Belle auditioned for ''The X Factor'' singing "[[Rumour Has It (Adele song)|Rumour Has It]]" by [[Adele]].<ref name="Adira-Belle Profile"/> Evelyn and Naomie were childhood friends and Temy and Kia met at an audition and through mutual friends.<ref name="Adira-Belle Profile"/> Adira-Belle were formed after each member auditioned individually in the fourth series.<ref name="X Factor Profiles"/> They cited Beyoncé, [[Destiny's Child]], [[En Vogue]] and Rihanna as their musical influences.<ref name="Adira-Belle Profile"/> Prior to entering ''The X Factor'', Adira-Belle worked at a chicken takeaway shop.<ref name="Live show 1"/>
Temy (formerly known as Temgazi Tshangase) was born in [[Swaziland]], [[Africa]] and began singing at the age of two.<ref name="Temy Bio"/><ref name="Temy Swazi">{{cite news|last=Mhlongo|first=Ntombi|url=http://www.times.co.sz/entertainment/89884-swazi-actress-in-x-factor-australia-top-12.html|title=Swazi actress in X Factor Australia Top 12|work=Times of Swaziland|date=31 July 2013|accessdate=23 August 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029211709/http://www.times.co.sz/entertainment/89884-swazi-actress-in-x-factor-australia-top-12.html|archivedate=29 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> She is the daughter of popular gospel singer and music producer Thulani Tshangase.<ref name="Temy Swazi"/> Temy did her primary education at Ka-Zakhali Private School, Khanyisile Private School and S.O.S in [[Mbabane]].<ref name="Temy Swazi"/> At the age of seven, Temy moved to [[England]] with her mother Thabisile Xaba-Jele and stepfather, and they lived there for four-and-a-half years.<ref name="Temy Bio"/><ref name="Temy Swazi"/> In 2006, she starred in the documentary film ''[[The Exodus Decoded]]''.<ref name="Temy Swazi"/> She moved to Australia the age of 11.<ref name="Temy Bio"/> Prior to entering ''The X Factor'', Temy was a student at Campbelltown High School of the Performing Arts with fellow ''X Factor'' contestant [[Jai Waetford]].<ref name="Temy Bio"/> Adira-Belle landed in the final showdown in week one with Barry Southgate after receiving the fewest public votes.<ref name="Week 1 Elimination"/> They were eventually eliminated from the competition after Keating, Minogue and Redfoo chose to save Southgate.<ref name="Week 1 Elimination"/>
===JTR=== {{Main|JTR (band)}} JTR are a boy band made up of brothers John (aged 23), Tom (aged 20) and Robin Lundback (aged 19).<ref name="JTR Profile">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584645/jtr/|title=JTR|work=The X Factor Australia|publisher=Yahoo!7|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Giles|first=Amber|date=3–9 August 2013|title=Brothers in Charms|journal=TV Week|publisher=Bauer Media Group|issue=31|page=15}}</ref> They auditioned for ''The X Factor'' singing "[[As Long as You Love Me (Justin Bieber song)|As Long as You Love Me]]" by Justin Bieber.<ref name="JTR Profile"/> JTR are originally from [[Sweden]] but moved with their mother to [[Cornubia, Queensland]] three months before auditioning for ''The X Factor''.<ref name="Live show 1"/><ref name="Dami JTR"/> They cite [[Dappy]], Justin Bieber, John Mayer, [[Gavin DeGraw]], Jessie J and Ed Sheeran as their musical influences.<ref name="JTR Profile"/> JTR landed in the final showdown in week three with Barry Southgate after receiving the fewest public votes, but were saved by Keating, Bassingthwaighte and Redfoo.<ref name="Week 3 Elimination"/> JTR were in the final showdown again in week four with Ellie Lovegrove, and after the judges decision went to deadlock, it was revealed that Lovegrove received the fewest votes and was eliminated.<ref name="Week 4 Elimination"/> JTR were eventually eliminated from the competition in week six, after Keating, Minogue and Redfoo chose to save Third Degree.<ref name="Week 6 Elimination">{{cite web|url=http://www.take40.com/news/42558/the-x-factor-australia-2013---jtr-sent-home-by-all-the-judges|title=The X Factor Australia 2013 – JTR Sent Home By All the Judges|publisher=Take 40 Australia. MCM Entertainment|date=30 September 2013|accessdate=1 October 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131003011248/http://www.take40.com/news/42558/the-x-factor-australia-2013---jtr-sent-home-by-all-the-judges|archivedate=3 October 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
JTR's debut single "Ride" was released on 3 February 2014, through Trinity Records.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/ride-single/id805999285|title=Ride by JTR|publisher=[[iTunes Store]]. [[Apple Inc.|Apple]]|accessdate=16 March 2014}}</ref> Their debut studio album ''Touchdown'' was released on 7 March 2014,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/au/album/touchdown/id785111689|title=Touchdown by JTR|publisher=iTunes Store. Apple|accessdate=16 March 2014}}</ref> and debuted at number 44 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Albums Chart]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=JTR |title=Discography JTR |publisher=Australian Charts Portal. Hung Medien |accessdate=16 March 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141203211917/http://australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=JTR |archivedate=3 December 2014 |df= }}</ref>
===Third Degree=== {{main|Third Degree (band)}} [[File:Third Degree 2013.jpg|thumb|right|Third Degree]] Third Degree was a mixed group that consisted of Kelebek (aged 18 from [[Albury]], New South Wales), Jacinta Gulisano (aged 19 from Sydney, New South Wales) and Jordan Rodrigues (aged 18 from Melbourne, Victoria).<ref name="Top 12"/><ref name="Third D3gree Profile">{{cite web|url=http://au.tv.yahoo.com/x-factor/article/-/18584693/third-d3gree/|title=Third D3gree|work=The X Factor Australia|publisher=Yahoo!7|accessdate=21 August 2013}}</ref> They cited Beyoncé, [[Eve (entertainer)|Eve]], [[Slaughterhouse (group)|Slaughterhouse]], Usher, [[The Black Eyed Peas]], Chris Brown, [[Missy Elliott]], Jessie J, Michael Jackson and [[Amy Winehouse]] as their musical influences.<ref name="Third D3gree Profile"/> Kelebek is of [[Filipino people|Filipino]] and German descent.<ref name="Kelebek Filipino">{{cite news|url=http://bayanihannews.com.au/2013/03/15/filipino-australian-talents-on-tour-of-the-philippines/|title=Filipino-Australian Talents on Tour of the Philippines|work=Bayanihan News|date=15 March 2013|accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref> She previously auditioned for ''The X Factor'' in the fourth season, under her birth name Vanessa Skrypczak, and made it to the top 24.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Giles|first=Amber|date=17–23 August 2013|title=Fainting Fits|journal=TV Week|publisher=Bauer Media Group|issue=33|page=7}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Mills|first=Tammy|url=http://www.bordermail.com.au/story/1431386/singing-for-headspace-1k-to-charity/|title=Singing for headspace: $1K to charity|work=[[The Border Mail]]|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=15 April 2013|accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref> Gulisano was a semi-finalist in the [[Australia's Got Talent#Series 3 (2009)|third series]] of ''Australia's Got Talent'', as a member of the singing trio Soundcheck.<ref name="Aquinas">{{cite web|url=http://aquinasmenai.catholic.edu.au/Newsletter090209.pdf |title=Aquinas has got Talent! |format=PDF |page=7 |publisher=[[Aquinas College, Menai]] |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=23 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091015170348/http://aquinasmenai.catholic.edu.au/Newsletter090209.pdf |archivedate=15 October 2009 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.starnow.com.au/clairemcguiness|title=Claire McGuiness|publisher=StarNow. StarNow Limited|accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref> She was a student at [[Aquinas College, Menai|Aquinas College]] in [[Menai, New South Wales]].<ref name="Aquinas"/> Prior to entering ''The X Factor'', Gulisano was a vocal coach and dance teacher.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.famouspa.com.au/FAMOUS_PERFORMING_ARTS/Teachers.html|title=Teachers|publisher=Famous Performing Arts|accessdate=23 August 2013}}</ref> In 2013, it was revealed she had been dating ''[[Dance Academy]]'' actor [[Jordan Rodrigues]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Giles|first=Amber|date=24–30 August 2013|title=X Factor Romances|journal=TV Week|publisher=Bauer Media Group|issue=34|page=6}}</ref>

However, the judges called them back to form a mixed group for the Groups category and they progressed to the home visits stage. Third Degree landed in the final showdown in week six of the live shows with JTR after receiving the fewest public votes, but were saved by Keating, Minogue and Redfoo.<ref name="Week 6 Elimination"/> Following the eliminations of Adira-Belle and JTR, Third Degree became the only remaining act in the Groups category. Third Degree received a recording contract with Sony Music Australia after they left the competition.<ref name="Signed to Sony"/> On 7 March 2014, it was announced that Kelebek had left the group, leaving Gulisano and Rodrigues as a duo.<ref>{{cite news|first=Chris|last=Georgakopoulos|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/newslocal/south-west/x-factor-australia-group-third-d3gree-disbands-after-kelebek-splits-for-solo-career/story-fngr8hxh-1226852441769|title=X Factor Australia group Third Degree disbands after Kelebek splits for solo career|work=Canterbury-Bankstown Express|publisher=The Daily Telegraph|date=12 March 2014|accessdate=23 May 2014}}</ref> Third Degree's name was later changed to The Clique and are no longer signed to Sony Music Australia.<ref>{{cite video|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qKG5F1z4oaQ|title=Third Degree New Name Announcement|work=[[YouTube]]|date=22 May 2014|accessdate=23 May 2014}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox saint |name=[[Saint]]
Louis Joseph Aloys Stanislaus Martin |birth_date={{birth date|1823|08|22|df=yes}} |death_date={{death date and age|1894|07|29|1823|08|23|df=yes}} |feast_day=12 July |venerated_in=[[Roman Catholic Church]] |image=Louis Martin 1.jpg |imagesize=220px |caption= |birth_name=Louis Joseph Aloys Stanislaus Martin |birth_place=[[Bordeaux]], [[Gironde]], [[France]] |death_place=[[Arnières-sur-Iton]], [[Eure]], France |titles= |beatified_date=19 October 2008 |beatified_place=Basilique de Sainte-Thérèse, France |beatified_by= [[Pope Benedict XVI]] |canonized_date= 18 October 2015 |canonized_place= [[Saint Peter's Square]], [[Vatican City]] |canonized_by=[[Pope Francis]] |major_shrine= |suppressed_date= |issues= }} {{Infobox saint |name=[[Saint]]
Marie-Azélie Guérin |birth_date={{birth date|1831|12|23|df=yes}} |death_date={{death date and age|1877|8|28|1831|12|23|df=yes}} |feast_day=12 July |venerated_in=[[Roman Catholic Church]] |image=Zélie Martin 1.jpg |imagesize=220px |caption= |birth_name= Azélie-Marie Guérin |birth_place=[[Saint-Denis-sur-Sarthon]], [[Orne]], [[France]] |death_place=[[Alençon]], [[Orne]], France |titles= |beatified_date=19 October 2008 |beatified_place=Basilique de Sainte-Thérèse, France |beatified_by= [[Pope Benedict XVI]] |canonized_date= 18 October 2015 |canonized_place= [[Saint Peter's Square]], [[Vatican City]] |canonized_by=[[Pope Francis]] |attributes= |patronage=}} '''Louis Martin''' (22 August 1823 – 29 July 1894) and '''Marie-Azélie "Zélie" Guérin Martin''' (23 December 1831 – 28 August 1877) were two married Roman Catholic French laypeople and the parents of five Roman Catholic nuns, including [[Thérèse of Lisieux]], a [[Carmelites|Carmelite]] [[nun]] who was [[Canonization|canonized]] as a saint of the [[Catholic Church]] in 1925. On 18 October 2015, the couple were also canonized as saints, becoming the first spouses in the church's history to be canonized as a couple.{{cite news|url=https://www.osv.com/osvnewsweekly/byissue/article/tabid/735/artmid/13636/articleid/17360/history-awaits-in-canonization-of-married-couple.aspx?ref=top10|title=History awaits in canonization of married couple|date=22 April 2015|first=J.J.|last=Ziegler|publisher=OSV Newsweekly|accessdate=4 November 2015}} ==Early life== ===Louis Martin=== Louis Joseph Aloys Stanislaus Martin was the third of five children of Pierre-François Martin and Marie-Anne-Fanny Boureau.{{cite book|url=http://static1.squarespace.com/static/52709303e4b08363c17ac8fd/t/54dc0127e4b01b81e4da47f3/1423704359484/BIOGRAPHICAL+PROFILE+OF+THE+VENERABLE+SERVANTS+OF+GOD.pdf|title=Biographical Profile of the Venerable Servants of God|publisher=Office of the Postulator General of the Discalced Carmelites|date=19 October 2008|accessdate=4 November 2015}} All his siblings died before reaching age 30. Although Louis intended to become a [[monk]], wishing to enter the [[Augustinian Order|Augustinian]] [[Great St Bernard Hospice|Great St. Bernard Monastery]], he was rejected because he did not succeed at learning Latin. Later he decided to become a [[watchmaker]] and studied his craft in [[Rennes]] and in [[Strasbourg]].{{cite web|url=http://louiszeliemartin-alencon.fr/en/la-famille-martin/louis-a-reliable-and-committed-man|work=The Martin Family|title=Louis a reliable and committed man|publisher=Sanctuaire d'Alençon|accessdate=4 November 2015}} ===Azélie-Marie Guérin=== {{moresources|section|date=October 2016}} Azélie-Marie Guérin was born in Gandelain, near [[Saint-Denis-sur-Sarthon]], [[Orne]], France. She was the second daughter of Isidore Guérin and Louise-Jeanne Macé.{{cite web|url=http://louiszeliemartin-alencon.fr/en/la-famille-martin/test-en|work=The Martin Family|title=Zélie, a modern woman|publisher=Sanctuaire d'Alençon|accessdate=4 November 2015}} She had an older sister, Marie-Louise, who became a [[Order of the Visitation of Holy Mary|Visitandine]] nun, and a younger brother, Isidore, who was a [[pharmacist]]. Her maternal family was from the Madré, in the neighbouring department of Mayenne, where her grandfather, Louis Macé, was baptised on 16 March 1778.{{cn|date=October 2016}} Zélie wanted to become a nun, but was turned away by the [[Daughters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul|Sisters of Charity of Saint Vincent de Paul]] due to respiratory difficulties and recurrent headaches. She then prayed for God to give her many children and that they would be consecrated to God. She later decided to become a lacemaker, manufacturing [[Alençon lace]]. She fell in love with the watchmaker Louis Martin in 1858 and married him, only three months later, on 12 July 1858, at the [[Basilica of Notre-Dame d'Alençon|Basilica of Notre-Dame]] in [[Alençon]]. Zélie's business became so successful that, in 1870, Louis sold his watchmaking business to go into partnership with her. ==Marriage and family== Although the couple lived as brother and sister for ten months after their wedding, they decided to live as husband and wife after a spiritual director encouraged them to do so.''Louis et Zelie Martin: une saintete pour tous les temps'', by Jean Clapier. Paris, Presses de la Renaissance, 2009, pp. 89-90 They would later have nine children, though only five daughters would survive infancy: #''Marie Louise'' (22 February 1860 – 19 January 1940), as a nun, ''Sister Marie of the Sacred Heart'', Carmelite at Lisieux; #''[[Agnes of Jesus (religious)|Marie Pauline]]'' (7 September 1861 – 28 July 1951), as a nun, ''Mother Agnès of Jesus'', Carmelite at Lisieux; #''[[Léonie Martin|Marie Léonie]]'' (3 June 1863 – 16 June 1941), as a nun, ''Sister Françoise-Thérèse'', Visitandine at Caen; candidate for sainthood since January 2015; #''Marie Hélène'' (3 October 1864 – 22 February 1870); #''Joseph Louis'' (20 September 1866 – 14 February 1867); #''Joseph Jean-Baptiste'' (19 December 1867 – 24 August 1868); #''[[Genevieve of the Holy Face|Marie Céline]]'' (28 April 1869 – 25 February 1959), as a nun, ''Sister Geneviève of the Holy Face'', Carmelite at Lisieux; #''Marie Mélanie-Thérèse'' (16 August 1870 – 8 October 1870); #''[[Thérèse de Lisieux|Marie Françoise-Thérèse]]'' (2 January 1873 – 30 September 1897), as a nun, ''Sister Thérèse of the Child Jesus and of the Holy Face'', Carmelite at Lisieux, canonised in 1925.{{cite web | url = http://www.thereseoflisieux.org/storm-of-glory-therese-from-18/ | title = Storm of Glory: St. Therese of Lisieux from 1897–2014| work = Saint Therese of Lisieux: A Gateway | first = Maureen | last = O'Riordan | accessdate = 18 October 2015}} As a father, Louis loved nature with a deep sentimental enthusiasm. It was from him that Thérèse inherited her passion for flowers and meadows, and for her native landscape, clouds, thunderstorms, the sea and the stars. He made pilgrimages to [[Chartres]] and [[Lourdes]], went to Germany and Austria, travelled twice to [[Rome]] and even to [[Constantinople]], and planned, but did not live to carry out, a pilgrimage to the [[Holy Land]].{{cite book | title = The Hidden Face | first = Ida | last = Görres | publisher = Ignatius Press | year = 2003 | authorlink = Ida Friederike Görres | page = 41}} Along with this desire for adventure was an impulse towards withdrawal; in Lisieux Louis arranged a little den for himself high up in the attic, a true monastic cell for praying, reading and meditation. Even his daughters were allowed to enter it only if they wished spiritual converse and self-examination. As in a monastery, he divided the day into worship, garden work and relaxation. As a jeweller and watchmaker, Louis loved the precious things with which he dealt. To his daughters he gave touching and naïve pet names: Marie was his "diamond", Pauline his "noble pearl", Céline "the bold one", and "the guardian angel". Thérèse was his "little queen ... to whom all treasures belonged".{{cite book | title = The Hidden Face | first = Ida | last = Görres | publisher = Ignatius Press | year = 2003 | page = 42}} ==Death== Zélie died of [[breast cancer]] on 28 August 1877 in Alençon, aged 45, leaving her husband and daughters. Her funeral was held in the basilica where she had married Louis.{{cite web|url=http://www.blogster.com/canadiancatholicblog/ste-thrse-lisieux | title=Ste. Thérèse of Lisieux Part 1 - Her Family|work=canadiancatholicblog|date=21 October 2007|accessdate=4 November 2015}} A few weeks later, Louis sold her lacemaking business and their house along Rue St. Blaise,{{cite web|url=http://louiszeliemartin-alencon.fr/en/venir-en-pelerinage/the-family-home|title=The family home|publisher=Sanctuaire d'Alençon|accessdate=4 November 2015}} and moved to [[Lisieux]], [[Normandy]], where Zélie's brother Isidore Guérin, a pharmacist, lived with his wife and two daughters. After Zélie's death, Pauline, Thérèse (Françoise-Thérèse), and Céline all became Carmelite nuns, along with a cousin, Marie Guérin. Léonie became a Visitandine nun at [[Caen]] after leaving the [[Poor Clares]].{{cite web|url=http://leoniemartin.org|title=Léonie Martin, Disciple and Sister of St. Thérèse of Lisieux|first=Maureen|last=O'Riordan|year=2013|accessdate=4 November 2015}} In 1889 Louis suffered two paralyzing strokes followed by [[Arteriosclerosis|cerebral arteriosclerosis]], and was hospitalised for three years at the Bon Sauveur Asylum in Caen. In 1892 he returned to Lisieux, where two of his daughters looked after him until his death on 29 July 1894 at Chateau La Musse near [[Évreux]].{{cn|date=October 2016}} ==Beatification== [[File:Saint Patrick Church (Columbus, Ohio) - relics of Louis & Marie-Azélie Guérin Martin, detail.jpg|200px|right|thumb|Relics of Louis and Marie-Azélie Guérin Martin at [[Saint Patrick Church (Columbus, Ohio)]]]] Louis and Zélie were declared "[[venerable]]" on 26 March 1994 by [[Pope John Paul II]]. They were [[Beatification|beatified]] on 19 October 2008 by [[José Saraiva Martins|José Saraiva Cardinal Martins]], the legate of [[Pope Benedict XVI]] in the [[Basilica of St. Thérèse, Lisieux|Basilica of Saint Thérèse]], [[Lisieux]].{{cite web|url=http://catholicsaints.info/saint-louis-martin|title=Saint Louis Martin|work=CatholicSaints.info|accessdate=4 November 2015}} A few months earlier, the Catholic Church had recognized the miracle of Pietro Schiliro, an Italian child cured of lung trouble at their intercession.{{cite web|url=http://louiszeliemartin-alencon.fr/en/la-famille-martin/les-etapes-du-chemin-de-la-canonisation/the-first-miracle-of-louis-and-zelie-martin-the-blessed|title=The first miracle of Louis and Zélie Martin, the Blessed|publisher=Sanctuaire d'Alençon|accessdate=4 November 2015}} For Louis and Zélie to be canonized, the church needed to find that God worked a second miracle at their intercession.{{cn|date=October 2016}} ==Canonizations== [[File:Louis and Marie-Azélie Martin.jpg|left|thumb|180px|Canonization tapestry in 2015.]] On 7 January 2013, [[Carlos Osoro Sierra]], [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Valencia in Spain|Archbishop of Valencia]], presided at the opening of the canonical process to inquire into the healing in 2008 of a girl named Carmen, who was born in Valencia four days before Louis and Zélie were beatified.{{cite web|url=http://louiszeliemartin-alencon.fr/en/la-famille-martin/les-etapes-du-chemin-de-la-canonisation/the-second-miracle-of-louis-and-zelie-martin-the-blessed|title=The second miracle of Louis and Zélie Martin, the Blessed|publisher=Sanctuaire d'Alençon|accessdate=4 November 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thereseoflisieux.org/my-blog-about-st-therese/2013/1/20/the-cure-of-carmen-is-this-the-miracle-that-will-make-blesse.html|work=Saint Therese of Lisieux: A Gateway|title=The cure of Carmen: Is this the miracle that will make Blessed Louis and Zelie Martin, the parents of St. Therese of Lisieux, canonized saints?|first=Maureen|last=O'Riordan}} Eight doctors testified that there was no scientific explanation for her cure.{{cn|date=October 2016}} The diocesan tribunal held its closing session on 21 May 2013, and the file was sent to Rome for review by the [[Congregation for the Causes of Saints]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thereseoflisieux.org/my-blog-about-st-therese/2013/5/28/vatican-to-investigate-presumed-miracle-attributed-to-blesse.html|work=Saint Thérèse of Lisieux: A Gateway|title=Vatican to investigate "presumed miracle" attributed to Blessed Louis and Zélie Martin, the parents of St. Thérèse of Lisieux. Will the healing of little Carmen make them saints?|first=Maureen|last=O'Riordan}}{{cite web|url=http://louiszeliemartin-alencon.fr/en/la-famille-martin/la-canonisation-dun-couple-exemplaire|title=Canonization of a model couple|publisher=Sanctuaire d'Alençon|accessdate=4 November 2015}} On 3 March 2015 [[Angelo Amato|Angelo Cardinal Amato]] announced informally that Louis and Zélie Martin would be declared saints during the [[Synod of Bishops (Catholic)|Synod of Bishops]].{{cite news|url=http://www.zenit.org/en/articles/canonization-of-st-therese-s-parents-to-coincide-with-synod-on-the-family|title=Canonization of St. Therese's Parents to Coincide with Synod on the Family|publisher=ZENIT|date=3 March 2015|accessdate=4 March 2015}} The Congregation accepted and promulgated the miracle on 18 March 2015.{{cite news|url=http://ncronline.org/news/global/pope-francis-recognizes-miracle-needed-declare-french-couple-saints|title=Pope Francis recognizes miracle needed to declare French couple saints|first=Cindy|last=Wooden|publisher=National Catholic Reporter|date=18 March 2015|accessdate=16 October 2016}} On 26 June 2015, ''Miracle of Life in Valencia'', a film produced by the Archdiocese of Valencia about the canonization miracle was released online in English.{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rvge_IFsN5k|title=Miracle of life in Valencia|date=25 June 2015|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=19 December 2015|via=YouTube}} The next day, at a consistory of cardinals in Rome, Pope Francis approved the decree for the canonization of Louis and Zélie Martin and announced that the ceremony would take place in October in Rome. On 18 October 2015, Louis and Azélie-Marie Martin were canonized as saints by Pope Francis.{{cite press release|url=http://www.news.va/en/news/280240|date=18 October 2015|publisher=News.va|title=Santa Messa con il Rito di Canonizzazione dei Beati: Vincenzo Grossi, Maria dell’Immacolata Concezione, Ludovico Martin e Maria Azelia Guérin|language=Italian|accessdate=16 October 2016}} ==Publications== In 2011, the letters of Zélie and Louis Martin were published in English as ''A Call to a Deeper Love: The Family Correspondence of the Parents of Saint Therese of the Child Jesus, 1863–1885'' ({{ISBN|0818913215}}). Although only 16 letters from Louis survive, many of Zélie's 216 letters give vivid details about the family's life and Louis's character as a father.{{cn|date=October 2016}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://louisandzeliemartin.org/ Saints Louis and Zelie Martin, the Parents of Saint Therese of Lisieux] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20131207082644/http://www.louiszeliemartin-alencon.com/eng/ The Shrine of Louis and Zélie Martin in Alençon] * [http://www.archives-carmel-lisieux.fr/english/carmel/index.php/couple-martin Web site of the Archives of the Carmel of Lisieux] * [http://www.leonie-martin.fr/ Web site Léonie Martin] {{Canonization}} {{Subject bar |portal1= Biography |portal2= Catholicism |portal3= France |portal4= Saints}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Martin, Louis}} [[Category:People from Bordeaux]] [[Category:Watchmakers (people)]] [[Category:1823 births]] [[Category:1894 deaths]] [[Category:19th-century venerated Christians]] [[Category:Beatifications by Pope Benedict XVI]] [[Category:Canonizations by Pope Francis]] [[Category:French Roman Catholic saints]] [[Category:Venerated Catholics by Pope John Paul II]]

Gabrielle Montgomery | relatives = }} '''Michael Cambias''' is a fictional character in the [[United States|American]] daytime drama ''[[All My Children]]''. He was portrayed by actor [[William deVry]], from January 23, 2003 to August 29, 2003, and as ghostly visions from September 23 to 26, 2003; October 9, 2003; November 11 and 13, 2003; December 3, 2003; January 16 to 23, 2004; February 16, 20, and 26, 2004; September 7, 14, and 15, 2004; and January 27 to 31, 2006. The character is one that lives in infamy due to the controversial [[rape]] storyline of ''All My Children'' heroine [[Bianca Montgomery]]. The event became one of the most debated topics within the soap opera medium and was nicknamed "[[Lord Voldemort|Voldemort]]," a title first coined by ''[[Television Without Pity]]'' message board members to mean "the storyline that shall not be named."{{cite news|first=Sarah |last=Warn |title=The Debate Over Bianca's Rape on All My Children |publisher=[[AfterEllen.com]] |date=June 2003 |accessdate=2007-12-23 |url=http://www.afterellen.com/archive/ellen/TV/amc-rape.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070709082516/http://www.afterellen.com/archive/ellen/TV/amc-rape.html |archivedate=2007-07-09 |df= }} ==Storyline== Character Michael Cambias is primarily remembered for raping [[Erica Kane]]'s [[lesbian]] daughter, [[Bianca Montgomery]]. His background shows him to be the spoiled, wealthy, and extremely arrogant son of '''Alexander Cambias, Sr'''. (later known as the '''Satin Slayer'''). He comes to Pine Valley with business partner [[Lena Kundera and Bianca Montgomery|Lena Kundera]] in a failed attempt to take over several prominent Pine Valley businesses, including Chandler Enterprises, Cortlandt Enterprises, Enchantment and Fusion Cosmetics. On a gloomy, rainy and thunderous night when the power is out in all houses of Pine Valley, Michael breaks into the boarding house Bianca resides at and rapes her to get back at Kendall and Erica for ruining his plans. Michael is later charged with raping Bianca, but to the community's utter disgust, he is acquitted due to a lack of physical evidence (an angry Lena even goes so far as to almost attack him after the acquittal). His after-trial gloating, wherein he states that he ''"owns Pine Valley, and everybody in it'',''"'' angers nearly everyone in hearing range and Jackson Montgomery, Bianca's uncle, warns Cambias's attorney to get him out of the courtroom, before the crowd becomes a [[Lynching|lynch mob]]. Eventually, he is found dead in a freezer outside of Pine Valley. His funeral is attended by most everyone who cares for Bianca, and their "eulogies" are laced with anger and hatred toward him. Lena even goes so far as to spit on his grave. His final resting place, fittingly enough, is in the city dump; [[Tad Martin (All My Children)|Tad Martin]] had earlier stolen Michael's body from the funeral home and filled the empty casket with rocks before throwing the body in the garbage. Though Kendall is initially the prime suspect in the murder, it is later revealed to be Bianca. Bianca had earlier confronted Michael and shot him to death in self-defense when he attempted to rape her again, but she repressed her memories of the event. When she recalls killing Michael and confesses, the judge who believed Bianca's story all along, leans hard on the prosecution not to file any charges against her. Eventually, it was discovered that when Bianca was raped, he impregnated her. She eventually gave birth to a daughter, named [[Miranda Montgomery|Miranda]]. Although Michael is her father, Bianca gave Miranda the last name Montgomery. ==Specific character detail == Character Michael Cambias was born on May 25, 1969. The writers had him die of a fatal injury sustained after a gunshot wound to the abdomen by Bianca Montgomery on August 28, 2003. ===Victims=== {| class="wikitable" ! Name !!
